DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-NATO Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III opened a new round of talks with allied leaders Sunday night on reducing U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. But his chances of shaping a NATO consensus on how to reply to the latest proposal by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were limited by the absence of a consensus within the Bush administration. U.S. sources, who demanded anonymity, said the Pentagon had not ``signed off'' on a U.S. response. It was not clear whether the delay was caused by a substantive disagreement or by the fact that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was away, starting a two-week trip to Asia. A senior Defense Department official traveling with Cheney said he heard a hint of such a story last week and that it wasn't his sense that the Pentagon is throwing up any kind of roadblocks. ``I have no sense we are the problem,'' the official said. He said Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, had been in constant contact with the Pentagon's representative at the talks, Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz, and ``I didn't sense there were any problems.'' Reflecting the lack of a firm U.S. position, officials said afterward that Baker was ``neutral'' in his presentation to the allies of the Gorbachev proposal. ``He basically just laid it (the proposal) out literally,'' said a U.S. official, who demanded anonymity. ``The secretary described it in neutral terms.'' As for the allies, the official said, ``The ministers felt they wanted to consider it for a longer period of time.'' Meanwhile, The New York Times reported that Baker told Soviet officials last week that the United States is now willing to receive preliminary Soviet proposals about reductions in nuclear arms that would go beyond those currently under negotiation. ``Up to now we have not been willing to discuss the Soviet ideas on Start II on the ground that we still have work to do on Start 1,'' the paper quoted a senior administration official. ``Now we are saying you can raise your ideas if you want to. We are getting to the point where we need to think a little bit about the next phase.'' Also on the agenda in Ottawa was talks on German reunification. The first session was requested by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to brief Baker on meetings Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Genscher held in Moscow with leaders of the Soviet Union. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas were invited to attend. Afterward, Baker and the foreign ministers of the 15 U.S. allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization arranged a caucus in advance of the opening Monday of an ``Open Skies'' conference with the Soviet Union and the six other Warsaw Pact nations. The purpose is to consider adoption of a proposal made last May by President Bush to open the countries to aerial surveillance as a way of allaying suspicions of secret military operations or preparations for surprise attacks. In his State of the Union speech Jan. 31, Bush proposed a ceiling of 225,000 on U.S. and Soviet troops on foreign soil in Europe, with a limit of 195,000 in Central Europe. Gorbachev, in a four-hour meeting with Baker on Friday in Moscow, countered with an initiative that would set the ceiling of 195,000 throughout Europe _ or 225,000 as an alternative _ without any sub-limit for Central Europe. One result would be more leeway for the Soviets to keep troops in Central Europe than under the Bush proposal. Currently, about 385,000 are in East Germany alone. Baker called Gorbachev's proposal ``very interesting,'' but said at a news conference Friday night in Moscow the Bush administration could not reply without consulting the allies. Still, discussion within the Bush administration itself apparently is still going on. The Pentagon and the National Security Council must weigh in with their recommendations. Within the alliance itself the debate could extend beyond the two days Baker is spending in Ottawa. So a consensus may not emerge by the time he flies home Tuesday night. Genscher requested the meeting with Baker as Baker's U.S. Air Force jet was en route from Bucharest on a 12-hour, 5,290-mile flight. Gale winds in the vicinity of Shannon, Ireland, where Baker's plane was due to refuel, forced it to divert to Lajes Air Base in the Azores. to Canada. German reunification is proceeding at a pace unanticipated by either the Americans or the Soviets. The two superpowers are trying to arrange a peaceful outcome, but they differ on strategy. Baker has endorsed a proposal that would keep the unified Germany in NATO, but without Western troops permitted in East Germany. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze has proposed an international plebiscite on the question of German reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Acid Rain Conference to Showcase 10-Year Study
DOC.TEXT: Scientists from around the globe gather in South Carolina on Monday to review a 10-year study of acid rain that may be the most comprehensive ever on the issue. About 1,000 researchers from 11 federal agencies spent $500 million compiling 28 separate reports on the causes and effects of acid rain and proposals to curb it. One conclusion of the study likely to provoke controversy at the conference is that acid rain generally isn't harming the nation's forests, said Joseph Barnard, a U.S. Forest Service researcher, who headed up the work of forest scientists, The Charlotte, (N.C.) Observer said in Saturday editions. The World Resources Institute, a Washington-based environmental group, said ``evidence is unambiguous'' that acid rain and ozone contribute to the deaths of trees in the South, East and West. The reports will be reviewed during the weeklong meeting on Hilton Head Island, then combined in a final document that will be used with computer models to devise emission-control strategies against acid rain. ``The whole purpose is to give outsiders a chance to critique the reports. It's a chance to get them out into the broader scientific community,'' said Chuck Herrick, a spokesman for the National Acidic Rain Assessment Program. The program was established by Congress 10 years ago to oversee the study of acid rain. About 600 scientists from 35 countries are expected to attend the conference, which runs through Friday. Acid rain is a combination of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide which mixes in the atmosphere and can be carried hundreds of miles before falling back to earth as rain, snow, fog and dust particles. It makes lakes and streams acidic, killing aquatic life. It can also kill trees and is harmful to the health of humans. Much of the pollution comes from power plants that burn high-sulphur coal, although other industrial facilities contribute. The National Acidic Rain Assessment Program's final report will be used to create 30 scenarios detailing the expected effects of acid rain in the future, and the effectiveness of various efforts to curtail acid rain. The report will make no recommendations on what should be done, however. ``The assumption then is the policy people will be looking at this and will be able to make their decisions,'' said Herrick, adding that the review is probably the most comprehensive ever compiled on acid rain. Last summer, President Bush unveiled a clean air bill to sharply reduce urban smog, toxic chemical air pollution and acid rain by the end of the decade. Bush's plan, which he called one of his top priorities, is before Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Neely Settles With TWA
DOC.TEXT: State Supreme Court Chief Justice Richard Neely said Sunday he has settled his lawsuit against Trans World Airlines for $12,500. Neely filed the lawsuit in Kanawha County Circuit Court after a July flight from Seattle to New York, alleging that TWA officials handled a luggage delay poorly. According to the lawsuit, Neely was shoved by a female employee while he was acting as an informal liaison for the approximately 150 passengers on his flight who were waiting for their luggage. Neely called the settlement satisfactory and said it involved no disciplinary action against any TWA workers involved. Phone calls to Don Morrison, TWA's director of public relations in St. Louis, weren't answered Sunday night.

DOC.HEAD: Six Escape From Maximum Security Joliet Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0405 to CORRECT to 4th Ld, sted 3rd. SUBS penultimate graf, `Terry W. ...,' to CORRECT Colburn's hometown to Bloomington, sted Fulton, Mo.
DOC.TEXT: Six convicts, including three murderers, escaped from a maximum-security prison early Sunday, apparently by cutting through metal bars, officials said. One was captured later in the day. The escapees, who had been in segregation cells at the Joliet Correctional Center because of disciplinary problems, were considered extremely dangerous, authorities said. Most were in their 20s. Tommy Munoz was captured shortly after 5:30 p.m. at his cousin's Chicago home by law enforcement officers who'd staked it out, said state Department of Corrections spokesman Nic Howell. Munoz, 22, was serving a sentence for narcotics violatins and intimidation. About 100 corrections officers specially trained to deal with escapes assisted state police and local law enforcement officers in the hunt. A search for the escapees with dogs and an airplane was called off earlier because they has apparently split up, said state Trooper Thomas Miller. The prisoners escaped from segregation cells, where they were kept for disciplinary problems, Howell said. Four of the inmates were doubled up in cells and the other two were in cells alone. Reports of when the prisoners escaped changed over the course o the day. State police originally reported the men were discovered missing at 4:55 a.m., but Illinois Department of Corrections spokesman Nic Howell later said the discovery was made after a 7 a.m. inmate count came up short. The inmates had to cut through bars on the cells, break a window, cut through bars outside the window and cross a fence to get away, Howell said. ``Obviously, this is a breach of security,'' he said. ``They shouldn't have had the materials to be able to cut with and should not have been able to cut like this without being noticed.'' The men may have been armed with cutting tools when they got away, Miller said. The prison, which has been plagued by overcrowding in recent years, is one of the state's four maximum-security facilities and one of two in Joliet, which is about 30 miles southwest of Chicago. The other in Joliet is Stateville Correctional Center. The prison houses 1,300 inmates, 500 more than it was built to hold. In addition to Munoz, Miller identified the escapees as: _Daniel Johnson, 24, of Buru, Tenn., imprisoned for murder. _James F. Allen, 40, of Chicago, imprisoned for three murders. _Dave Rodriguez, 21, of Chicago, imprisoned for murder. _Terry W. Colburn, 21, of Bloomington, Ill., imprisoned for burglary. _Ronald Roach, in his 20s, of Wyoming, Ill., imprisoned for burglary.

DOC.HEAD: Investigate Killings Of Four In Bowling Alley
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-14, `Police said ...,' with 15 grafs to UPDATE with most leads not panning out, that daughter was counting money when men walked in, other comments from first officer on scene, conditions of wounded upgraded; picks up 15th graf, `Police Lt. ...'
DOC.TEXT: Police hunting the killers who shot three children and an adult to death and wounded three other people at a bowling alley said Sunday they plan to share composite drawings of two men with Mexican authorities. ``We have information right now there may be a possible individual from Mexico who has done something like this,'' said police Capt. Fred Rubio. Las Cruces is 45 miles north of the Mexican border. Within an hour of the shootings Saturday morning, police set up 10 roadblocks around Las Cruces, but no arrests resulted and the barriers were taken down by evening, Rubio said. Teams of officers were checking out about 100 pieces of information telephoned to Las Cruces police from other law enforcement agencies and the public, he said. ``Most of the leads we have followed and looked into have not panned out,'' he said. Police said two men walked into the Las Cruces Bowl on Saturday, herded seven people, including four children, into an office in the front of the building; made them lie on the floor and shot them in the backs of their heads. The men then set fire to the office in an effort to cover up the crime, police said. ``The owner's daughter had opened the safe and was counting the money when all this happened,'' said police Sgt. Phil George. Rubio said it appeared the motive was robbery and that money was missing. He did not disclose the amount. He said the seven victims were the only people in the bowling alley at the time and the robbers apparently ``decided to rid themselves of any witnesses.'' No neighbors interviewed Saturday heard the shots, but they said their dogs started barking around 7:30 a.m. One of the victims called police around 8:30 a.m. from the smoldering office. ``She was crying and hysterical when she called,'' said George, who was the first officer on the scene. ``I've never been involved in a case so gruesome,'' George said. ``One of the survivors was moaning and groaning, so I went to her and we started getting them out of the office.'' Firefighters helped move the dead and wounded from the flames. Authorities said junior league games for youngsters had been scheduled to start at 9 a.m. ``If there had been any more people, I'm sure they would have been shot,'' Rubio said. Helicopters and planes from the U.S. Customs Service, Army and Border Patrol assisted in the search for the two men reported by witnesses to be driving a tan or green van or utility vehicle. The bowling alley, which also has a restaurant and bar, video games and pinball machines, is in a mixed commercial and residential area in this city of 55,000 people. The building is on a corner of an intersection with a large parking lot around it and a vacant lot on one side. The wounded _ two adults and a 12-year-old _ originally were in critical condition at Memorial General Hospital, but two of the victims' conditions were upgraded Sunday afternoon to serious and the third was listed in good condition, police said. Police would not release any other details. Police Lt. Jerry Fariss said Sunday he had spoken with two of the survivors. ``One of them was able to give a description that tends to match the one we've got,'' he said. Rubio said shooting children so young ``doesn't make any damn sense. These people are just coldblooded people.'' ``It's not the city it was when I used to roam the streets,'' he said. There were two homicides in Las Cruces in all of 1989 and six so far this year, according to Rubio. ``Everybody's in shock around here. I told my husband I want to move from here,'' said neighbor Bobbi Avalos. ``I don't think I could ever go in there (bowling alley) again.'' The dead were identified as bowling alley employee Steve Teran, 26, daughter Valerie Teran, 2, stepdaughter Paula Holguin, 6, and Amy Houser, 13. Teran's cousin, Larry Alvarez, said Audrey Teran, Steve's wife and the mother of Valerie and Paula, was at work elsewhere at the time of the shootings. ``She's back home with her mother,'' Alvarez said Sunday. ``They took her back home (to Silver City) last night.'' Alvarez said Teran, also of Silver City in southwest New Mexico, had worked at the bowling alley two years and did a variety of jobs. ``There is a desperate need for justice here,'' Alvarez said. ``I don't see how anybody can shoot children.''

DOC.HEAD: Kabul Government Still Confident
DOC.TEXT: A general claimed Saturday the government has made strong military gains toward vanquishing the U.S.-backed guerrillas in the nearly one year since the Soviet troop withdrawal. Lt. Gen. Abdul Haq Ulumi also claimed guerrilla losses were 10 times those of the army in the past year. He declined to give a specific figure. The insurgents, who are based in neighboring Pakistan, said the only route to peace is on the battlefield, not across the negotiating table. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters in Moscow that Washington was willing to permit Afghan President Najib to remain in office while peace talks are conducted between the Soviet-backed government and the U.S.-armed insurgents. Referring to reports that Moscow and Washington were considering compromises that could include a scaling down of aid to the opposing Afghan sides, Ulumi said it was ``very much toon too early to speak about what we should give up and what they (the guerrillas) should give up.'' First there should be a cease-fire, international guarantees, elections and formation of a broad-based government, said Ulumi, a ranking member of the Central Committee of the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. Speaking to foreign journalists through an interpreter, he said that since the Soviets ended nine years of military presence in mid-February, Najib's troops proved their ability to go it alone against the insurgents, known as the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. The government still holds every major city and has made deals with scores of local commanders who once fought on behalf of the mujahedeen. But fighting continues in much of the countryside and around several key provincial capitals. Mujahedeen rockets still fall on Kabul, although with far less frequnecy than a year ao. The last Red Army troops crossed the border home on Feb. 15, 1989, but Moscow continues massive supplies, by land and air, of weapons and food.

DOC.HEAD: Bloomingdale's Robbed of As Much As $500,000
DOC.TEXT: Armed men stole as much as $500,000 in receipts from Bloomingdale's flagship department store Saturday evening, police said. Two or three gunmen wearing ski masks surprised three security guards in the basement of the well-known Manhattan store at about 7:30 p.m., said Sgt. Pete Berry, a police spokesman. The guards were leaving a freight elevator with the day's receipts in a locked cart when the robbers, armed with a sawed-off rifle and a gun, handcuffed two of them together and forced all three to lie on the floor, he said. The robbers got away with between $250,000 and $500,000, Berry said. He said it was not immediately known how much was in cash.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Glitch Makes Galileo Camera Keep Snapping After Venus Flyby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with decision to restart camera, attempt overnight pictures. Picks up 9th graf, `Galileo's other...'. Should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Galileo's camera shutter snapped uncontrollably for five hours Saturday after the spacecraft zipped around Venus, but officials said it shouldn't endanger the $1.35 billion, eight-year mission to Jupiter. Engineers at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory shut off the television camera while diagnosing the problem, which apparently involved faulty software that made Galileo's computer send incorrect commands to the camera, mission director Neal Ausman said. They decided Saturday night to send new computer commands to Galileo to restart the camera so it could take a series of photographs of Venus late Saturday and early Sunday, said NASA spokesman Bob MacMillin. The engineers believed an error in computer commands they sent to Galileo made the shutter snap when it wasn't supposed to, and they were ``pretty certain there's nothing wrong with the computer or camera,'' he said. Galileo cruised around Venus at 9:59 p.m. PST Friday, coming three to four miles closer to the planet than the planned point of closest approach 10,028 miles above the Venusian surface, said mission science and design manager Bill O'Neil. The camera appeared undamaged, but its shutter opened and closed twice per minute 468 times over five hours, Ausman said. As planned, only 16 pictures taken late Friday and early Saturday were stored on Galileo's tape recorder, Ausman said. The malfunction didn't harm those pictures, and the 452 unwanted shutter snappings were ``just like taking pictures with no film in the camera,'' project manager Dick Spehalski said during a Saturday news conference. However, the problem threatened five dozen other photos the spacecraft was supposed to take in the coming week to make a time-lapse movie of Venus' clouds and winds, said project scientist Torrence Johnson. He said scientists weren't too upset because about 20 U.S. and Soviet spacecraft have visited Venus previously, and the main purpose of Galileo's flyby was to use Venus' gravity to speed the spacecraft for its long trip to Jupiter. Galileo's other sensors will continue observing Venus as the spacecraft speeds away from the planet, Spehalski said. Galileo was deployed Oct. 18 from space shuttle Atlantis on a looping 2.4-billion, six-year route that requires Venus and Earth to be used as gravity slingshots to hurl the spacecraft to Jupiter. Once there, the spacecraft will deploy a probe to study Jupiter's atmosphere, then orbit the giant gas planet for at least two years in a mission that costs $1.35 billion. When the glitch developed at 1:41 a.m. PST Saturday, Galileo already had snapped the 16 pictures to study Venusian wind and cloud patterns and search for lightning that might indicate erupting volcanoes beneath the clouds. The camera was shut off at 6:30 a.m. after engineers determined it was following incorrect computer commands, Ausman said. Eight minutes later the erroneous commands stopped without explanation. Despite the trouble, ``there was no point when the spacecraft was in jeopardy,'' he said. Galileo's TV camera is perhaps the most critical instrument on the spacecraft. It is expected to take pictures of Jupiter 20 to 1,000 times more detailed than those returned by the Voyager 1 and 2 spacecraft in 1979. The TV camera has a shutter, which opens to throw light on an electronic sensor. Data from that sensor can be sent to Earth, where it is assembled into a photograph. ``We're dealing with a fresh spacecraft and prototype software,'' so NASA knowingly risked a glitch in exchange for trying to photograph Venus even though the spacecraft is still in the shakedown part of its trip to Jupiter, Johnson said. For now, the pictures and data gathered in the flyby are being stored on Galileo's tape recorder, and won't be sent back to Earth until October when the spacecraft is close enough to transmit the material. That antenna now can be used only for communications to keep Galileo operating. Galileo's roundabout route to Jupiter is an indirect result of the 1986 explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger and killed seven crew members. After the tragedy, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration decided against using powerful, volatile, liquid-fueled Centaur rockets to launch spacecraft after they were deployed from shuttles. Instead, Galileo was launched by a weaker booster after it was released from Atlantis' cargo bay. That made it necessary to use the gravity of Venus and Earth to help speed and aim Galileo toward Jupiter. A Centaur would have propelled Galileo to Venus in only two years.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sentenced to Alcoholism Treatment in Children's Drownings
DOC.TEXT: A woman who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the drownings of her three children must serve at least one year in a treatment program for alcoholism. Aimee Dees of Chatom allegedly was driving drunk when her van plunged off a rural road into Weeks Bay on March 16, 1988, drowning her children, Kari Maxwell, 8, Morgan Cameron Maxwell, 6, and Kristen Mallory Dees, 2. Mrs. Dees initially was charged with murder in the children's drownings, but struck a plea bargain. Under the agreement approved by Circuit Judge Thomas B. Norton Jr. on Friday, Mrs. Dees must serve one to three years in an alcohol treatment program and five years of supervised probation. She also must pay $1,000 for each charge to the state Victims' Compensation Fund and must serve 1,000 hours of community service dealing with alcohol problems. In addition, she must pay court costs and the cost of her treatment. If she fails to meet the requirements of the sentence, she can be sent to prison for 15 years. The sentences were five years to be served consecutively. The father of two of the children, Homer B. Maxwell III of Atlanta, said he would prefer to see Mrs. Dees go to jail. ``She has been in and out of drug treatment programs and has not stopped yet,'' he said. ``She deserves to pay.'' Maxwell has filed a civil lawsuit against Mrs. Dees in the case. District Attorney David Whetstone said he was pleased with the outcome. ``Manslaughter would be the worst the jury would have given her anyway,'' Whetstone said. Mrs. Dees must report to the Camel Back Vista Drug Treatment Center in Scottsdale, Ariz., on Monday. The center is part of the Arizona State Department of Corrections.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Steers Bus to Safety After Driver Collapses
DOC.TEXT: The driver of a chartered Greyhound bus carrying 31 people collapsed Saturday from an apparent heart attack, but a passenger alertly grabbed the steering wheel and safely stopped the vehicle, authorities said. ``There was no warning at all,'' said Buddy Fryxell, a 52-year-old businessman from Little Rock, Ark., who grabbed the wheel. ``The bus just started weaving, and he threw his head back. ``I knew things were very wrong,'' he said. The driver, Walter Marshall, 59, based in Grand Junction, was later pronounced dead at University Hospital. He suffered a heart attack at about 9:30 a.m., not long after picking up the Little Rock Ski Club at Stapleton International Airport, officials said. The bus was on Interstate 70 when the driver collapsed. ``I thought it was going to flip, so I grabbed the wheel and got it back into the lane,'' Fryxell said. ``I was standing up with one foot on the brake, but he was still in the seat with his foot lodged against the accelerator.'' Another passenger, Don Colaianni, then pulled Marshall's leg from the gas pedal, and Fryxell steered across three lanes and stopped the bus. No passengers were injured. Two doctors on board the bus tried to revive Marshall, officials said. ``When he was loading luggage on the bus, I noticed he was sweating profusely,'' said one doctor, Doug Stroud. ``I asked him if I could help, and so did others, but he said no. The exertion probably precipitated the heart attack.'' Greyhound sent another bus, and the club resumed its trip, arriving in Aspen Saturday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Launched on Soviet Space Program's First Profit Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 3rd pvs `The launch...' to CORRECT to four sted five U.S. astronauts; pickup graf 4 pvs `Solovyov and...'
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts rocketed into orbit Sunday on a mission designed to turn a profit of over $40 million, a first in the 32-year history of the Soviet space program. Riding a Soyuz TM-9 capsule, flight commander Anatoly Solovyov and engineer Alexander Balandin soared into cloud-streaked skies over the Baikonur space complex in Soviet Kazakhstan on schedule at 9:16 a.m. Moscow time. The launch of the three-stage rocket, shown live on Soviet television, was also witnessed by four U.S. astronauts flown to the space center in Central Asia for the event. The American guests included Dan Brandenstein, who commanded the 11-day flight of the space shuttle Columbia in January; Ron Grabe; Paul Weitz; and Jerry Ross. Solovyov and Balandin were scheduled to dock later with the space station Mir and to relieve two fellow Soviet spacemen now spending their sixth month in orbit. The new cosmonauts are to spend six months in space. All systems were reported normal by Soviet television eight minutes after the Soyuz capsule and booster rocket lifted off atop a column of orange-white flames. The cosmonauts now aboard the Mir, Alexander Viktorenko and Alexander Serebrov, are scheduled to return to Earth on Feb. 19. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pressures have increased on the once sacrosanct Soviet space program to prove its usefulness to the shortage-plagued economy. Some Soviet lawmakers have even called for funding cutbacks, saying the country can ill afford costly space missions when it cannot supply citizens with a reliable supply of meat and potatoes. The Soyuz TM-9 mission, however, is designed to to put to use the Kristall module, described by the government newspaper Izvestia as the first orbital factory for the full-scale manufacture of technological and biotechnological materials in the near-weightless conditions on Mir. Through use of Kristall, to be launched for linkup with Mir on March 30, a profit of up to $41 million is expected, the official Tass news agency said. It is the first time a profit has been part of a manned mission in the history of the Soviet space program.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Dead in Eruption of Mount Kelud
DOC.TEXT: Mount Kelud in East Java has erupted, darkening the sky with a mammoth dust cloud and wrecking dozens of homes, a news agency said Sunday. At least 16 people were reported killed and more than 50 injured. The official Antara news agency said 15 of the deaths and 48 injuries from Saturday's eruption were in Blitar Regency. In Kediri Regency west of the 5,679-foot peak, one person was found dead and eight injured, the agency said. The eruption, which began shortly before noon, spewed volcanic dust, sand and gravel into the air. The cloud blackened the sky within a radius of more than 30 miles, the report said. In the town of Blitar, about 22 miles south of the mountain, dust from the eruption reportedly piled up more than six inches in some areas. The eruption destroyed more than 150 houses, Antara said. It said most of those killed were caught in ruins of damaged buildings. It said local scientists had detected ground motion early Sunday near the volcano and were continuing to monitor the situation.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Offers Romania $80 Million in Food Assistance
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates thruout; changes byline
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III offered Romania $80 million in food aid on a brief visit to Bucharest Sunday morning, but told the country's interim leaders that the United States expects continued movement toward democracy. ``We want to do our part to assist the transition to political pluralism and a free market economy,'' Baker said after meeting with interim President Ion Iliescu and Premier Petre Roman. Baker is the highest-ranking American official to visit Romania since December's revolution which toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. His visit came amid controversy over the new Provisional Council of National Unity, which will run the country until elections on May 20 and includes opposition parties for the first time. Many of the 18 party leaders who met Baker said they told him the old National Salvation Front Council, which took power during the revolution, has kept its grip on power in the new council. Several said the Front is a guise for the old Communist Party. Baker said he told Iliescu and Roman that ``the betterment of relations of the United States with Romania will depend on fully free, fair elections and the respect for human rights and the rights of minorities.'' Terming the changes since the overthrow of Ceausescu ``a reform movement that clearly I think we have to applaud,'' Baker told reporters after meeting with the officials that his visit was intended ``to encourage the continuation of the process of reform.'' ``It's very important to the United States that the commitment to reform towards democracy is expressed in the conduct of fully free and fair elections,'' said Baker. The U.S. official announced the humanitarian aid package at a meeting with leaders of 18 parties and four unions at the residence of U.S. Ambassador Alan Green Jr. ``I was pleased, in the meeting I had with the president and the prime minister, to say that we're prepared to make available to Romania, on highly concessionary terms, $80 million in food assistance,'' he said. A State Department official said the assistance would include 500,000 metric tons of feed grain and 7,500 tons of butter. Asked by reporters whether the United States would restore Romania's favored-nation trade status, Baker said: ``We are re-examining now our position, just as we are re-examining it with respect to some other countries in Eastern Europe. ``Whether we move towards that depends on ... continued movement towards free and fair elections, openness, freedom and democracy,'' he said. Baker said Romanian officials assured him ``they are committed to fully free and fair elections.'' Roman said after his meeting with Baker that he viewed the visit ``as the beginning of a new relationship on a new basis, taking into account the new democracy (in Romania).'' ``From now on we can speak of American aid as not just humanitarian, I mean aid to rebuild,'' Roman added. Baker made several appearances outside the ambassador's residence, one with ethnic Hungarian priest Laszlo Toekes by his side. The authorities' efforts to remove Toekes from his home in the western Romanian city of Timisoara sparked December's revolution. ``Mr. Tokes, through the brave example that he set for freedom of religion and for democracy, really served as the catalyst for the reform effort that we see taking place in Romania,'' Baker said. ``We've been talking with the reverend about the importance of respecting the rights of minorities in America and the importance of freedom of religion.'' Toekes said, ``The key problem in the democratization of Romanian society is the solving of the minorities problem.'' Some 2 million ethnic Hungarians and 220,000 ethnic Germans live in Romania, together with some 20,000 Romanian Jews. Corneliu Coposu, president of the National Peasant Party, the country's largest opposition group, said Baker asked whether the opposition was afraid of the government and whether there was a proper atmosphere for the elections. ``The collective answer was that there is fear, and it is a sustained action of fear,'' he said. Baker also asked whether the opposition was happy with the May 20 election date. ``We told him the elections should be postponed until September and everybody agreed,'' Coposu said. Radu Campeanu, president of the National Liberal Party, the second-largest party, said there should be a distinction between humanitarian aid and political aid. Political aid, he said, ``should be granted only after serious guarantees of democracy, guarantees which don't exist today.'' He said Baker's visit was a morale booster for the opposition, which did not significantly change the government's position. Adrian Manolache, 37, president of the Romanian Ecology Party, said the opposition told Baker that a lot of Front members were Communist officials under Ceausescu. ``The Front wants to lead the country to totalitarianism,'' he said. ``It's not possible to have democracy without opposition.'' Asked about the impact of Baker's visit, Manolache said: ``This visit is very important for our people, for our parties, and for democracy because James Baker promised to us help and funds for our electoral campaign.'' He said Baker didn't say how much help. ``Mr. Baker said that he is ... near the opposition and the parties and near democracy in Romania,'' he said. Baker also met student leaders, representing the students who were in the forefront of the revolution. Gabriel Nuta, 23, a University of Bucharest student representing the Student League, said he told Baker to ``keep a tough position'' when it comes to the Front. ``They are just talking a lot about democracy, but doing very little about it,'' he said. ``They are using Stalinist methods.''aid. Baker stopped in Bucharest after a brief visit to Bulgaria following talks in the Soviet Union. His next stop is Ottawa, where he will attend a conference on ``open skies.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Boxing Heavyweight Bout in Limbo
DOC.TEXT: James ``Buster'' Douglas' knockout victory over heavyweight champion Mike Tyson was in dispute Sunday after the referee admitted giving a long count when Douglas was knocked down earlier in the fight. The presidents of the World Boxing Council and World Boxing Association said they would not decide on a winner until their executive committees met later this month. The announcements by the WBA and WBC came seven hours after the fight in a news conference attended by Tyson and the referee, Octavio Meyran of Mexico. Douglas knocked out Tyson in the 10th round. But two rounds earlier, Tyson had knocked down Douglas. Tapes show that in the eighth round the referee picked up his count three seconds after the timekeeper's count, giving Douglas that extra amount of time to rise. ``I'd like to recognize my mistake,'' Meyran said. Tyson, who was 37-0 with 33 knockouts going into the fight, said he should be declared champion. ``I knocked him out before he knocked me out,'' Tyson said. Douglas did not attend the news conference, but said earlier at his hotel suite that he got up when he heard the referee count ``eight.'' It was not known how boxing's third major governing organization, the International Boxing Federation, would handle the controversial match. The IBF was not represented in Tokyo. WBC President Jose Sulaiman said a second Tyson-Douglas bout could be ordered. Tyson said he wanted a rematch.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede PAARL
Mandela Freed After 27 Years in Jail; Violence Breaks out in Cape Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with 26 people injured by police in Cape Town, Mandela rally apparently canceled. Pickup 4th, `Mandela, dressed...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela walked through a prison gate to freedom Sunday, welcomed joyfully by blacks as their leader after 27 years in jail for choosing to take up arms against apartheid. But violence broke out an hour later as Mandela's motorcade arrived at City Hall in Cape Town after a 35-mile drive from the prison complex in Paarl. At least 26 people were reported injured when riot police with shotguns opened fire after dozens of black youths smashed shop windows. Some youths retaliated by hurling bottles at the officers. Tens of thousands of people had gathered outside City Hall to hear Mandela address a welcoming rally. When the violence began, anti-apartheid leaders told the crowd to disperse, but there was confusion about whether another venue for the rally would be found. First aid workers said at least 20 people were hospitalized after being hit by birdshot, and at least six other people were being treated at a first aid station. Earlier, throngs of supporters, many waving flags of Mandela's African National Congress, broke into a thunderous cheer as he and his wife, Winnie, walked hand in hand through the gateway of Victor Verster prison in Paarl. The Mandelas gave clenched-fist salutes to the hundreds of supporters who had waited for hours outside the prison to welcome the nationalist leader. Mandela, dressed in a dark suit and tie, appeared solemn and dignified as he and his wife walked to a white BMW sedan and climbed in. He broke into a broad smile as the car set off slowly toward Cape Town in a police-escorted motorcade. Supporters reached out to touch the car as it passed and waved flags of Mandela's recently legalized ANC. Mandela raised his hand in salute to the crowd. Scores of policemen stood guard in the bright sunshine, and a small army of photographers and television crews from across the world frenetically took the first pictures of Mandela as a free man. ``I'm too much happy,'' said Nelson Dlula, a black teen-ager in the crowd. He wore a khaki outfit decorated with the ANC's green, gold and black colors. The state-run South African Broadcasting Corp. gave live television coverage to the release. ``This is the moment the world has been waiting for,'' said the television reporter at the scene. ``The sun is shining on South Africa.'' Mandela, 71, was to make a statement to the press in Cape Town after his release from imprisonment since 1962, then address a rally at City Hall. Three hours before the scheduled start of the rally, thousands of people _ mostly blacks but also some whites _ began assembling in the plaza outside City Hall, many wearing T-shirts with Mandela's picture. In Johannesburg, hundreds of young blacks, joined by a few whites, ran through downtown streets shooting, ``Viva ANC'' after the release. Traffic police patrol cars cleared the way for them. In Soweto, the sprawling black township outside Johannesburg where Mandela has his home, crowds of supporters danced and sang in celebration, many under umbrellas because of a steady rain. The decision to free Mandela was announced Saturday by President F.W. de Klerk, who had met Mandela the previous night. He described the black leader as ``committed to a peaceful solution.'' De Klerk, who lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC on Feb. 2, expressed hope that Mandela's release would lead to racial reconciliation. Mandela has offered to serve as mediator in arranging talks between the government and the ANC on a post-apartheid constitution that would give voting rights to the black majority. Mandela has been serving a life sentence after he a conviction of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-led government. Many South African blacks consider him their paramount leader, and he would be a favorite to win the presidency if blacks were allowed to vote. Mandela's freedom has been a longstanding demand of black leaders in South Africa, as well as governments and human rights groups abroad, and the decision drew immediate international praise. De Klerk, in his historic speech Feb. 2, lifted bans and restrictions on the ANC and other opposition groups, scrapped some state-of-emergency regulations, declared a moratorium on hangings, and promised to free Mandela unconditionally. These concessions met most, but not all, of the ANC's conditions for negotiations. The organization, and Mandela, also have demanded freedom for all political prisoners and an end to the state of emergency. P.W. Botha, who de Klerk succeeded in August, had offered to free Mandela in exchange for a public renunciation of violence, but Mandela refused. Under South Africa's system of apartheid, the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Humpback Whale Rescued from Fishing Net
DOC.TEXT: A baby humpback whale that became caught in fishing nets was rescued Sunday after an American marine biologist dived into the sea and cut the mammal loose. Fisherman Abdullah Khadouri spotted the 21-foot dark gray whale trapped and dying in about 130 feet of water at the mouth of Shutaifi Bay, close to Muscat harbor. Fishermen alerted the coast guard, who called in scientists from the Oman Marine Science Center. Jonathan Mee, 29, from San Francisco, who is working at the center, managed to free the whale after a dozen dives. Once freed, it swam out toward Fahal island off the northern coast and was seen heading toward the open sea, Mee said. ``It was still alive when I got to it initially, but it was in great distress,'' he told The Associated Press. ``Its tail was free but the rest of its body was caught in thick rope. Its eyes were closed very tightly and it was making whimpering noises which reverberated through the water.'' Mee said he could not tell how long the whale had been entangled. ``We believe it may have been traveling with its mother before losing its way and becoming caught in the nets,'' he said. The last humpback whale sighted in Oman was on Christmas Eve in 1988 when three adult whales were beached off the eastern coast. They were released, and a school of dolphins led them to open sea.

DOC.HEAD: Tremor Shakes Turin; No Injuries or Major Damage
DOC.TEXT: A sharp earthquake jolted this northern industrial city Sunday morning, causing some panic but no casualties or serious damage. The tremor, which occurred at 8 a.m., registered 4.2 on the Richter scale and had its epicenter just west of the city, seismologists said. The quake cut electricity for about a minute throughout Turin, set off car and burglar alarms and sent many residents rushing out of their houses. Police and fire department switchboards were flooded with calls from alarmed citizens. Authorities said a few old buildings suffered cracks, but no major damage was reported. A quake of magnitude 4 on the Richter scale can cause moderate damage. The scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels Claim Capture of Key Port
DOC.TEXT: Government troops and secessionist rebels battled for a fourth day Sunday for Ethiopia's vital Red Sea port of Massawa, state radio said. The Sunday morning broadcast by the government-controlled station conflicted with an earlier claim by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front that it had captured the city. That claim was made in a broadcast Saturday night by the ``Voice of the Broad Masses of Eritrea,'' the rebels' clandestine radio station. The government broadcast did not directly deny the rebel claim but said fighting was continuing around the port, one of only two on Ethiopia's Red Sea coast. Massawa is a key staging point for emergency food donated through the United Nations for an estimated 4 million people facing famine in northern Ethiopia this year. The state radio said Ethiopia's army and navy were ``paying heavy sacrifices'' to defend the city, but it gave no sources for its report. Ashagre Yigletu, deputy prime minister for social affairs, said Saturday the renewed fighting around Massawa had effectively halted the relief effort. The United Nations hoped to ship some 700,000 tons of food in the next few months to northern drought victims, most of them in Eritrea and neighboring Tigre provinces. Most of that aid would have been delivered by ship to Massawa, although detailed plans for its distribution have not been worked out. The rebels broke an almost year-long lull in fighting in Eritrea by launching a massive offensive Thursday that clearly had the capture of Massawa as a primary objective. In the first three days of fighting, the rebels claimed to have destroyed eight government brigades totaling about 12,000 troops, most of them entrenched along the 40-mile road linking Massawa with the provincial capital of Asmara. The Eritrean rebel attack erupted as the government appeared to be containing another offensive in the far south by a separate insurgent group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front. Foreign Minister Tesfaye Dinka told diplomats in Addis Ababa on Saturday that the Eritrean offensive appeared aimed at taking pressure off the Tigrean rebels. While they do not share common goals, the two insurgent groups have long maintained a loose alliance and have been known to coordinate their attacks against government forces. The Tigrean rebels launched their own offensive in late August, sweeping south and east out of Tigre into the neighboring provinces of Wollo and Gondor. A government counteroffensive begun in January appeared to have halted and in some areas pushed back the Tigreans' southern drive, which at one point came within 75 miles of the capital. In what has become Africa's oldest war, the Eritreans have been fighting since 1961 for independence for Ethiopia's northernmost province, once an Italian colony. The Tigrean rebels took up arms 14 years ago in an attempt to topple President Mengistu Haile Marian. They say they want to replace Mengistu's socialist regime with a government modeled after that of Albania, the last hard-line Communist nation in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Appeal to World Leaders to Help Stop Rushdie Threats
DOC.TEXT: More than 160 writers from across the globe appealed to world leaders Sunday to help stop the death threats against British author Salman Rushdie. The writers, including Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, a playwright, signed a statement prepared by the International Committee for the Defense of Salman Rushdie and his Publishers. It appeared in more than 20 newspapers worldwide. Rushdie has been in hiding under police guard since Feb. 14, 1989, when the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran accused him of blaspheming Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses'' and ordered his death. The edict was repeated on Friday by Khomeini's successor, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. ``We call on world leaders and all those in positions of influence to renew their efforts to end the persecution of Salman Rushdie and his publishers,'' said the writers' statement. ``We wish to restate that it is the right of all people to express their ideas and beliefs and to discuss them with their critics on the basis of mutual tolerance, free from censorship, intimidation and violence.'' The writers said that by expressing his right to freedom of expression, Rushdie was committing no crime. It noted, however, that opponents of his book have attacked bookshops in Britain and made threatening phone calls to Rushdie's publishers. In March, more than 1,000 writers from around the world signed a statement supporting Rushdie's right to freedom of expression and repudiating the death threat. It appeared in 62 newspapers and periodicals in 22 countries. Sunday's statement was signed by Rushdie's wife, American novelist Marianne Wiggins, by Nobel Prize winners Joseph Brodsky and Sir William Golding, playwrights Arthur Miller and Harold Pinter, Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood, and poets Allen Ginsberg and Bei Dao. South African writers Breyten Breytenbach and Nadine Gordimer, director-screenwriter Hanif Kureishi, and authors Catherine Cookson, Antonia Fraser, Kazuo Ishiguro, Edna O'Brien, Larry McMurtry, Toni Morrison, Susan Sontag and Kurt Vonnegut also were among those who signed it.

DOC.BYLINE: Thousands Turn Out For Mongolian Demonstration ^By CHARLENE L. FU
DOC.TEXT: Mongolians stirred up by the Soviet Communists Party's decision to relinquish its monopoly on power demanded Mongolia's Communists do the same in a rally Sunday that drew thousands of people, a source said. About 4,000 to 5,000 Mongolians attended the three-hour demonstration in front of the Lenin Museum in Mongolia's capital, Ulan Bator, said a foreign source contacted by telephone from Beijing. It was the fifth demonstration called by the Mongolian Democratic Union, founded in December by artists and intellectuals. The rally was called late Wednesday or Thursday, the source said, after the Soviet Communist Party voted to relinquish its decades-old hold on political power. Mongolia, ruled by Communists since 1921 and long a client of the Soviet Union, has cautiously followed the Soviet lead in embracing ``perestroika,'' or reform, but apparently not quickly enough for some of its citizens. Some speakers Sunday called for the resignation of President Jambyn Batmonh and the Politburo and criticized Premier Dumaagiyn Sodnom for the nation's ``stagnant'' economy. But the speakers stressed that they were not against the party, just opposed to its monopoly on power, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Indeed, two banners showed the union working with the party to combat bureaucratism. One depicted the union on one side of a saw and the party on the other side, cutting down a tree representing the bureaucracy, he said. Other banners gave a glimpse of some of the complaints and concerns of the Mongolian people. Some said ``Livestock to the herdsman,'' ``If people are rich, the state will be rich,'' and ``Is it true we are saddled by loans,'' a reference to the Soviet Union's massive loans to Mongolia, put at $5.5 billion by some economists, the source said. Unlike previous rallies, which were dominated by union officials, speakers Sunday included a taxi driver, a factory worker, an elderly woman, a coal miner and a herdsman from the countryside, the source said. Many said they were members of the union, which claims a total membership of 60,000. Some speakers recounted stories of union members being fired from their jobs or lectured because of their political activities. The union has called for an end to Communist Party influence over government affairs, debate on setting up a multiparty system, a full-time parliament and investigations of past repressive regimes. The source said Sunday's rally was peaceful with almost no police or military presence. He said the museum apparently is not one of the sites where demonstrations were banned by the city council three weeks ago. Union spokesmen said meetings were being held in other parts of the country. No plans were announced for future rallies, but the union said it still planned to hold a one-day congress next Sunday, although no location has been found. The source said the Mongolian press had reported the formation of other political groups. Newspapers and other reports say a Green Party and a Mongolian Patriotic Unity Front, which appears to be acting as a mediator between the Communist Party and the democratic union, have been founded, he said. Mongolia is a nation of 2 million scattered across the vast deserts and grasslands of eastern Asia between China and the Soviet Union. Its economy and culture have long been dominated by the Soviet Union. The Russian Cyrillic alphabet was officially adopted in 1946, and traditional Mongolia script was banned until about five years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Beginning To Drop U.S.-Soviet Trade Barriers
With AM-Baker-Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Top trade negotiators from the Soviet Union and the United States sit down for the first time Monday in an effort to begin dismantling the barriers that have prevented normal trade relations between the two superpowers for nearly a half-century. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz will be meeting with a Soviet delegation headed by Yuriy N. Chumakov, deputy minister of foreign economic relations. Both sides are working under a tight deadline trying to hammer out a wide ranging agreement in advance of the June summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. The administration hopes that normalizing trade relations between the two nations will give a boost to the Soviet economy and lend economic support to the political reforms being undertaken by Gorbachev. In announcing the start of talks last week, Hills said the administration's goal was to ``encourage economic reform within the Soviet Union as it moves toward a more market-driven economy.'' As part of the trade agreement, which would have to be approved by Congress, the United States would waive high tariffs that in some cases boost the duties on Soviet goods by 10 times over tariffs imposed on similar goods from other countries. The high tariffs have been required under a 1974 law known as the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which erected the trade barriers on the basis that Moscow was prohibiting Soviet Jews and other dissidents from leaving the country. Bush has signaled that the administration is ready to seek a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment based on actions the Soviets have taken in the past year to boost Jewish emigration. Granting the lower tariffs requires completion of a trade agreement, something Bush has said he hopes to be able to sign when he meets in June with Gorbachev. U.S. consumers would see lower prices for such popular items as Soviet vodka, which by one estimate could drop in price by $1.25 a bottle, and for luxury items such as Russian furs. Through the first 11 months of 1989, Soviet imports to the United States totaled just $658 million, far below even China, which had imports of $11.05 billion during the same time period. U.S. export sales to the Soviet Union totaled $3.82 billion through November, resulting in two-way trade of $4.48 billion. The administration is predicting that the trade figure could jump to between $10 billion and $15 billion within the next two or three years. American farm groups are watching the current trade negotiations with keen interest. Three-fourths of U.S. export sales to the Soviet Union involve American farm products and the Soviets reportedly have stated they will not approve a new grain sales agreement with the United States until they are granted the lower tariffs on their products. Many analysts, however, question the administration's projection on how much a new treaty could mean in increased trade, noting that the Soviet economy is facing severe problems at present which make it difficult for the country to afford imports from abroad. ``I am not all that optimistic about significant increases in trade flows until the Soviet economy is reformed,'' said Richard Kaufman, an expert on Soviet affairs with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ``The reforms that have captured world attention so far have all been on the political and social level.'' Robert Cullen, editor of Soviet-American Trade, a newsletter on the subject, said that the trade agreement will help Gorbachev more politically than it will boost trade between the two countries. ``Even with a trade agreement, the fundamental barriers between the Soviet Union and America, such as not having a convertible ruble, are not going to be alleviated,'' Cullen said. One primary area of dispute in the trade talks is expected to be differences over how the waiver of the Jackson-Vanik tariffs will be accomplished. The administration would like a three-year trade agreement with annual presidential review and waiver of the high tariffs. The Soviets, however, would like to see the tariffs removed permanently as a way of building confidence among business leaders that trade relations will remain stable in coming years. Micah Naftalin, national director of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said his organization favors one-year waivers. ``The country is still extraordinarily unstable and we should take it step by step.'' The administration will come to the bargaining table seeking a trade agreement guaranteeing the protection of American-patented products from piracy, an arbitration method to settle business disputes and provisions to allow either country to impose temporary trade restrictions if a domestic industry suffers injury because of an unexpected surge of imports. Congress has let the administration know that it expects to be consulted as the negotiations progress. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, put Hills on notice last week that such consultations will be necessary to win congressional approval of any deal that is negotiated.

DOC.HEAD: After Mandela's Release: South Africa Faces The Real Challenge
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Once the euphoria over Nelson Mandela's release dies down, South Africa will still face the enormous challenge of ending its centuries-old racial divisions and building a new nation. Black and white leaders say a major era in the country's history is coming to an end with the impending demise of white-minority rule. But the future is foreboding, they warn, with many obstacles and the threat of conflict ahead. South Africans must peacefully solve the country's problems and find a way to live together in equality after 40 years of apartheid, leaders say. But the white government and its opponents appear to be far apart, with whites insisting on a special role in the future despite black objections. ``Now there can be no going back. Irreversibly, South Africa has been placed on the path to its new future,'' The Sunday Times said in an editorial reflecting the views of a growing number of South Africans. While the search for peace is likely to be long and difficult, changes that would have been unthinkable even a year or two ago are already taking place. President F.W. de Klerk's decision to free Mandela and end bans on black opposition groups after years of armed conflict stunned many whites and blacks. He pledged to find ``a new dispensation'' that would end the exclusion of the country's 28 million blacks from political power. De Klerk says he opposes black majority rule and that a new constitution must include protection for ``group rights'' to ensure whites are not swamped in a future democratic state. The government says it will also retain, for now, such apartheid legislation as laws segregating residential districts. While the government declines to outline its position in talks on a future constitution, governing National Party officials say they favor splitting the country into a series of racially based, semi-independent cantons or counties. The cantons would be united under a federation that would oversee economic cooperation and other national issues. Critics reject such plans as ``apartheid in another guise'' and the ANC and other opposition groups say they will accept nothing less than total democracy. Mandela has indicated he will not bend on his insistence on equal rights. ``We must work toward a common destiny, and that can only be achieved through a non-racial society and not one in which whites continue to demand special political treatment,'' Mandela was quoted as saying by the South African Press Association. The 5 million whites in South Africa control the economy, and there is a huge gulf between the prosperity of most whites and the bleak poverty of the great majority of blacks. But while de Klerk and Mandela attempt to find a peaceful solution, there are many whites and blacks who will oppose any compromise and insist on total power for their side alone. Many whites are unhappy about the steps de Klerk has taken, and the opposition Conservative Party is attempting to force an election to oust the government. Political observers say de Klerk's white support is uncertain and he has to move quickly and decisively. Many whites looked worried or scared as they watched cheering and singing blacks surging through parts of central Johannesburg on Saturday after Mandela's release date was announced. A handful of blacks taunted whites, yelling ``Freedom is coming! Whites get out!'' A few furious whites lashed out, hurling bottles and insults at the blacks. An hour after Mandela's motorcade reached Cape Town city hall after his release Sunday, riot police clashed with black youths, and more than two dozen people were reported injured. Government leaders are worried about a violent reaction by extreme right-wingers, and security officials are braced for terrorism. Some political analysts have raised the possibility of a military coup, but the government insists it has the full support of the defense forces. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups face major divisions. The ANC is split between moderates and hard-liners favoring a military campaign, and some black groups oppose any negotiations with the white government. Mandela faces the challenge of trying to organize a broad coalition to present a united front to both the government and to more militant black groups. Mandela's task is likely to be easier than de Klerk's since many blacks regard him as their leader. Despite the enormous challenges, many whites and blacks appear hopeful they can solve their differences peacefully and find a way to live together without being tied down by the past.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Renfrew is The AP's bureau chief for South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Shooting at Nakasone's Campaign Office
DOC.TEXT: Police on Sunday arrested an ultra-rightist accused of firing several shots inside the campaign office of former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, the second attack on a Japanese politician in less than a month. Nakasone was not in the office at the time, and none of the 11 people inside was injured, police said. The attack, following the Jan. 18 shooting of Nagasaki's mayor, heightened concern that ultra-rightist groups are becoming increasingly violent after keeping a low profile during a year of mourning for the late Emperor Hirohito. Japanese rightsts revere the imperial family and are believed to be dissatisfied with Nakasone's and other governing Liberal Democratic Party leaders' links to an influence-buying scandal. They also are unhappy with the government's willingness to hear debate on whether the state should fund several coronation ceremonies for Emperor Akihito. Rightist groups, their vans painted in drab military colors, were out in force Sunday for a national holiday that marks the founding of the Japanese nation. Police said Koji Konishi, 23, entered the Nakasone campaign office in Takasaki city, 60 miles northwest of Tokyo, and fired three shots at a television set, a campaign poster and a doll symbolizing good luck. Police said Konishi identified himself as a member of the rightist Seiji Kessha Kokuyukai (Political Organization for Those Concerned About the Nation). Police said Konishi told them he didn't intend to kill anyone but dislikes Nakasone and wanted to ``create a ruckus'' to show the rest of Japan how the politician had ``made a fool of the Japanese people.'' Katsumi Kobayashi, a Nakasone aide, said he had no idea what Konishi's motive might have been and said the office had received no threatening phone calls or letters. He said a rightist was arrested in Tokyo last spring for planning an attack on Nakasone, who served as prime minister in 1982-87. ``We cannot allow free democracy, free elections to be trampled on by such acts of violence,'' Nakasone told reporters. Nakasone, who is seeking re-election to the lower house of Parliament, was delivering a speech to supporters elsewhere in the city when the attack occurred. Last year, another member of Konishi's group, which police say has fewer than 20 members and is based in Tokyo, severed a finger and sent it to then-Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, Nakasone's successor, to protest ``dirty politicians.'' Police estimate the number of ultra-rightists in Japan at 120,000 in roughly 820 groups. Only 10 days after the official mourning period for Emperor Hirohito ended on Jan. 8, the mayor of Nagasaki, Hitoshi Motoshima, was shot in the back as he was leaving City Hall. A member of a rightist group, Kazumi Tajiri, has been charged with attempted murder in the attack. Motoshima had received numerous death threats after saying in December 1988 that Hirohito shared responsibility for Japan's participation in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Unification, Yes _ But Some Say Slow Down
DOC.TEXT: Sigrid Kluge says she welcomes the Soviet green light for German reunification, but she fears developments are moving too quickly and threaten to swallow up her country. ``I want unification, not colonization,'' the young mother said Sunday as she pushed her daughter in a stroller across East Berlin's huge Alexander Square. The drive toward unification gained a boost on Saturday, when West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had agreed that a decision on the issue ``is the sole right of the German people,'' including the time frame and the method. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Sunday the Soviet leadership cleared the way for German unification because Moscow officials believe it will improve European stability. While it is almost impossible to judge the nationwide reaction to the developments, many East Germans queried at random Sunday were wary about the rapid pace of events in their country, which until four months ago was under the grip of a hard-line Communist regime. Some appeared especially concerned by Kohl's assertion that a reunification plan could be presented by the end of this year. ``We should wait until our economy is stronger, so that we can have a say in forming a new Germany, with all the best points of both countries,'' said Ms. Kluge, an office clerk. But West Germans say it is the reported near-collapse of the East German economy that makes unification so pressing now. Ms. Kluge was worried about the possible loss of East Germany's extensive social services. The services are designed to provide literally cradle-to-grave security for all citizens, although the social safety net is unraveling. ``As a single mother, I don't know what I'd do without all the state child care and other benefits we have here,'' Ms. Kluge said. Edith Puechner, 52, a high school teacher from Leipzig, said things are happening too quickly for people to adapt. She appeared concerned by Kohl's assertion that unification could be approved by the end of the year. ``We have to adjust to both democracy and a new economic system, and that takes time,'' Ms. Puechner said. ``People are going to be shocked by unemployment. Many will have to be trained for jobs in entirely different areas.'' With East Germans still heading West at a rate of 1,800 per day, none of those questioned in East Berlin disagreed that unification was inevitable. The only uncertainty appeared to be how soon and on what terms. Some felt unification could not come soon enough. ``There's no use maintaining this system any longer. It's time to just dump it,'' said Rudolf Mueller, a 56-year-old garment worker. ``Most of my friends and family have left already. I sometimes feel like the only one who's still here.'' ``Unification as fast as possible is the last chance for our country,'' said Hans-Christian Schlesinger, 37, who runs his own business selling work clothes. ``I've been struggling along for years with my business. I have to deal with so many restrictions and complications,'' he said. Schlesinger and his wife, Marita, said they have attended meetings with visiting West Germans to get advice on how to run private businesses. ``We're just starting to organize ourselves now, and the general feeling about the future is pretty optimistic,'' he said. None of those interviewed favored a unified Germany being part of NATO. Instead, all spoke out for German neutrality. Most said that only neutrality would convince neighboring countries they have nothing to fear from a unified Germany. They also argued against adding to either NATO or the Warsaw Pact at a time when the world is moving toward disarmament. Some expressed dismay at the ``aggressive'' turn they say their revolution has taken. ``I find this `Germany united fatherland' business very dangerous,'' said Juergen Ritter, 50, a manager in a state-run oil company. He was referring to a slogan frequently chanted at demonstrations in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed as Bus Plunges off Mountain Highway
DOC.TEXT: A bus filled with skiers hit a barrier and veered off a snow-covered mountain highway Sunday, and four people were killed and three were seriously injured, authorities said. Swiss rescue service workers said the bus was taking Italian tourists from the Swiss ski resort of St. Moritz to Milan. Police reports said the bus overturned several times after plunging off the highway and came to rest on its roof about 150 feet down the mountain. An unknown number of injured were taken to three nearby hospitals in Switzerland and Italy. Authorities said they had no initial information on the number of passengers on the bus.

DOC.HEAD: Andy Hits the Road: Lots of Nice Backdrops for TV _ And a Few Voters
DOC.TEXT: It was just after sunrise on day two of Andrew Young's campaign trip for the Georgia Statehouse, and when the oceanographic vessel Cape Hatteras docked along the Savannah River he went aboard to shake hands. Few, if any, of the North Carolina-based scientists on the research ship can vote in Georgia. But it'll look great on TV. And that was part _ maybe even most _ of the point as Young, former congressman, former ambassador to the United Nations, former mayor of Atlanta, launched his bid to become Georgia's first black governor in a campaign stressing media savvy over race. Reporters accompanying the Democrat joked about the ``stealth'' campaign seemingly able to slip in and out of towns without meeting an actual Georgia voter. But everywhere Young went, he was followed by his film crew snaring footage for the all-important TV spots that Georgia viewers won't see for months. Gov. Joe Frank Harris, a Democrat, is barred by the state constitution from running for a third consecutive term, just as Young was barred last year from seeking his third consecutive term as Atlanta mayor. The consensus is that Young, a popular black leader facing a crowded field of white candidates, is assured of finishing in the top two in the July 17 Democratic primary. Unless someone gets more than half the vote, the top two finishers will face each other in a runoff Aug. 7. Young's campaign is hard at work on a barrage of campaign commercials he'll unleash in those final weeks. ``People aren't paying attention yet now,'' said Frank Greer, Young's media guru, watching the Savannah River filming. Under the direction of Greer, who masterminded the media push as Virginia's Doug Wilder became the nation's first black governor last fall, little is left to chance, and anything can be a photo opportunity. The docking of the Cape Hatteras was more than a coincidence; a Young volunteer said the campaign had sent word to the ship and offered the crew an opportunity to be on TV with a real live political superstar. The backdrop for the filming was a big bridge under construction _ a bridge whose funds Young voted for, years ago, as a congressman from Atlanta. When a reporter surmised the connection, he got a congratulatory bear hug from the ebullient Greer. In Augusta, a visit by Young to the new River Walk development was ignored by most of the local media. A half hour of handshaking snared three tourists from Delaware, a man from Virginia and a couple of shopkeepers. But the crew got some great film of Young and his wife, Jean, nuzzling by the river. If all this seems sort of cynical, Greer explained that in 1990, in a state of 6 million people, you just don't meet many voters down at the courthouse square. ``In this day and age, the way you meet voters is through the media,'' Greer said. But two traditional courthouse speech stops last week showed that Young is pretty good when he does speak to actual voters. In the southeast Georgia town of Waynesboro, Tuesday's itinerary called for a meeting with local officials. But when a crowd of 75 or so greeted Young, he hopped up the courthouse steps and went to work _ no text, no microphone, just his message of new businesses, new jobs, a commitment to abortion rights and a public vote on a lottery. The next day, Young delivered the only formal speech of the four-day tour, to a crowd of 250 at the courthouse in Thomasville. It was a special event for Young as he spoke, tearfully, about beginning his ministerial career in the small southern Georgia town some 35 years ago. In an interview last week while his campaign van rolled through eastern Georgia, Young said he enjoys campaigning and likened his first statewide race to his travels organizing voting rights drives in the heyday of the civil rights movement. Like Wilder in Virginia, Young isn't directly mentioning the race question; there are no emotional entreaties to white voters to give him a chance. ``The word `black' very seldom comes up in the polling,'' he said. ``We don't ask racial questions, and people don't raise 'em.''

DOC.HEAD: Nursing Homes Resisting Movie Licensing Fees
DOC.TEXT: Hit films like ``Ghostbusters'' and ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' are forbidden videos at some nursing homes that gave up movies rather than meet Hollywood's demands they buy a license to pop a cassette into the VCR. The nursing homes say they should be treated like ordinary homes _ exempt from videocassette copyright restrictions _ when residents gather in a common living area to watch a movie. ``When people come to a nursing home or a retirement home it is for life and it is their home,'' said Stella Muller, leisure director for Marquette Manor in Indianapolis. ``We don't see why we can't have a gathering in the front parlor and show a movie.'' Hollywood takes a different view. The motion picture industry lumps nursing homes in the same category as libraries, colleges, churches, prisons, oil rigs and other institutions that show home videos to groups of people. Such organizations are required to buy a public performance license, as do movie theaters, for each copyright video they show or they can purchase an annual ``umbrella'' license giving them the right to show unlimited videos from certain studios. Nursing home officials say a typical fee would be $3.65 per bed per year, or $730 for a home with 200 residents. The nursing homes are backing legislation pending in the House and Senate that would allow unlicensed public viewing of videos in a ``hospital, hospice, nursing home or other group home providing health or health-related care and services to individuals on a regular basis,'' as long as the facilities do not charge for the viewing or further retransmit the material. Sen. William Roth, R-Del., first introduced the legislation in 1988 after receiving a letter from 10 elderly residents of Emily P. Bissell Hospital, a state-run nursing home in Wilmington, Del. ``It is not our choice that we are here, but we are, and our lives are now changed in many, many ways,'' the residents wrote. ``If the staff ... could show us some of the movies available on videocassette, it would certainly bring us a lot of pleasure.'' Barbara Dixon of the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents major Hollywood production companies and distributors, said MPAA is working with congressional staff to find a compromise that would address nursing home concerns without setting ``a precedent that we might come to regret later on.'' ``If a movie's shown in an individual room ... that is probably not a violation of the copyright law. But if it's shown in a public accommodation area where it can be viewed by large numbers of people then you run into a legitimate concern,'' she said in an interview last week. The legislation would exempt health care facilities under the ``home use'' exception contained in copyright licensing laws, as is non-commercial viewing of films or videos in individual residences. The measure is supported by the American Association of Homes for the Aging (AAHA), the American Health Care Association, the National Association of Activity Professionals and other groups representing the elderly. ``Residents should be able to view these films in their residences or homes the same way all of us watch films with our own families in our own living rooms,'' AAHA, which represents non-profit nursing homes, said in a recent legislative alert to its members. Because of the licensing dispute, some nursing homes no longer have movie nights, show only classics on which the copyrights have expired or encourage residents to rent their own videos to watch in their bedrooms. Some have purchased umbrella licenses, while others ignore the copyright restrictions and hope they don't get caught, officials said. The licensing push took off in 1986 when the Motion Picture Licensing Corp., based in Stamford, Conn., was created by three veterans of the movie business to sell public performance licenses to various organizations. Company chairman Peter Kuyper said the firm is involved in discussions aimed at resolving the licensing dispute ``without legislation,'' but he declined to comment further. The company's promotional literature says fees vary depending on the nature and size of the expected audience and how often movies are to be shown.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Freed After 27 Years in Prison
URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with additional Mandela quotes, first aid workers reporting one death. Pickup at rally, one death reported. Pick up 18th pvs, `Dr. Aslam...
