In June 1988 a Lynx helicopter was knocked down by sustained IRA gunfire at Forkhill, County Armagh. The IRA filmed a large team of men in open countryside tracking the helicopter and firing at it with heavy and light machine guns. They later released a video of the shooting. There have been fears among security officials that the IRA had obtained SAM-7 missiles from Libya to target military flights. None has been used to date and there was no suggestion one was used Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Says Bush Needs Arms Control Architects, Not `Carpenters'
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee criticized the Bush administration's arms control position Sunday as being put together by ``carpenters rather than architects,'' lacking a broad view. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said the administration needs to take a look at U.S. weapons systems as they relate to arms control and an apparent willingness by the Soviets to disarm. ``It's going to be awfully hard for this administration to say we've had a breakthrough in negotiating with the Soviets, we're going to reduce arms by about 30 to 40 percent and then come up and say we want two missiles _ two of them mobile; we want a new B-2 bomber; we want an SDI program to go forward full steam _ all of these things at one time,'' Nunn said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``I don't think that's going to sell,'' he said. Nunn said Bush's armed forces modernization plans do not take into account some of the possibilities in arms control, like getting rid of the MX rail mobile missile in exchange for the Soviet SS-24, which is also a based on railroad cars, and moving toward a policy of no multiple-warhead missiles. ``Our arms control position is really being done by carpenters rather than architects,'' he said. ``I don't think in Congress there's going to be a lot of receptivity to going forward with huge weapon systems unless there is a strategic concept that fits into the arms control.'' He also criticized the timing of Bush's appearance last week at U.S. military war games in California and his comments in support of the Strategic Defense Initiative at a time when the Soviet Union was voting to reduce the power of the Communist Party. ``Well, these military exercises have to go on, but I did think it was curious the president chose this moment in history to participate in a war game and give it tremendous visibility,'' Nunn said. ``I think that's somewhat out of sync with the events that are taking place.'' Nunn's comments came as Secretary of State James A. Baker III was en route to Ottawa, Canada, for a NATO-Warsaw Pact ``open skies'' conference on surveillance and other techniques for exchanging military data between East and West. At the Ottawa conference, Baker was to continue discussions with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on troop reductions in Europe and weapons cuts. The talks made progress last week while Baker was in Moscow, when a near-agreement was reached between the United States and Soviet Union on cuts in chemical weapons and long-range nuclear missiles. If negotiations work out in Canada, the slight differences between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on troop cuts are expected to be smoothed out, setting the stage for an agreement later this year between the NATO and Warsaw Pact alliances to remove about 400,000 Soviet and 100,000 American soldiers from Europe. The talks in Moscow produced an agreement that Bush and Gorbachev would sign accord in June, providing for the destruction of all their chemical weapons in 10 years _ if all other nations capable of making poison gas sign a treaty.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The solitude that fosters crooning in the shower is helping University of Georgia students master their do, re, mi's and shed their inhibitions about singing in public. Music professor David Smith uses an electronic voice analyzer in a room that once was a restroom to help future elementary school teachers overcome a lack of confidence in their singing abilities. The voice laboratory still has a sink and soap dish, but other toilet fixtures have been removed. Smith said the solitude of the laboratory is intentional, but the fact that it's located in a former restroom is strictly the result of space limitations. ``The activity itself is designed to be done in isolation so that they would not be so self-conscious,'' he said. ``I would assume singing in the shower might be the same thing, where they would not have an audience to entertain.'' Smith said students who are self-conscious about singing respond much better to musical activities that give them feedback without any human involvement. So an electronic device measures vocal performance digitally and gives the students a score. A meter shows them whether they are sharp or flat. It may not make opera singers out of them, but the teachers-to-be learn to be more at ease and more effective in leading youngsters in classroom singalongs, he said. ``Students can develop their skills in a fairly fun, non-threatening way,'' he said. ``It has a subtle, video-game approach.''

Harold Kopp thought the candy bar he bought at a shopping center was going to cost him $357 instead of some loose change. The same afternoon, Dorothy Newmann returned home from the same center $357 richer. But Kopp and Ms. Newmann found each other through a classified ad and the money went back to his pocket, leaving both feeling richer. ``I had just come out of the drug store,'' Kopp, 59, recounted Saturday. ``I got my blood pressure taken, and I bought a candy bar. I stopped for a minute to clean out my pocket ... and that's when the money clip fell out.'' Ms. Newmann, 57, found it Wednesday afternoon, but, as she puts it, ``I could not keep it. It might be an elderly man.'' Friday, she got the idea to check the classified section of The Stuart News. There, she saw an ad placed by Kopp. ``We had run it already and I figured if no one saw it Thursday it was hopeless. I was ready to kiss the money goodbye,'' Kopp said. ``But my wife convinced me to run it one more day, so we did. And that did it.'' Ms. Newmann called the Kopps and arranged a meeting, at which Kopp described the clip to her satisfaction. She handed it over. ``He kissed the money,'' Ms. Newmann said. Then he peeled off three $20 bills from the clip and gave them to her. ``We had a grand old time,'' Kopp said.

DOC.HEAD: Kaunda Urges ANC To Suspend Guerrilla Campaign
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda Sunday urged the African National Congress to suspend its guerrilla campaign in South Africa following the release of ANC leader Nelson Mandela. But Kaunda, long one of the South African government's staunchest critics, also said the ANC should maintain its military capability in case of violence by white right-wing extremists in South Africa. ``Until we know which way the ultra-rightists are going it is important that the armed struggle should only be suspended, not abolished,'' Kaunda told The Associated Press at his official residence in Lusaka. ``Certainly, I think the ANC should suspend the armed struggle for the moment but they should not be tempted to destroy their armed forces,'' he said. Kaunda has allowed the ANC to base its exile headquarters and guerilla facilities in Zambia and they have been targets of sabotage and military attacks by South Africa. He also said he believed it was premature to lift international economic sanctions before the United Nations discusses the South African situation on June 30. ``That will be the time for all of us to look back at what de Klerk will have done by way of establishing the root for abolishing apartheid,'' said Kaunda, chairman of the six-nation African Frontline bloc neighboring South Africa. Kaunda said he telephoned South African President F.W De Klerk late Saturday to offer him his encouragement. He gave no other details of their conversation, which took place a few hours after De Klerk announced plans for Mandela's release Sunday. Kaunda said he believed the ANC should ``encourage De Klerk along the path by talking.'' ``The time for talking has come,'' he said. The ANC has said it will not end its guerrilla campaign in South Africa or declare a unilateral cease-fire until several conditions are met, including the government lifts the state of emergency, releases all political prisoners and withdraws troops from black townships. The organization has said it will not begin talks with the government until the same conditions are met. Kaunda described the ANC's conditions as proper but did not indicate whether he would try to persuade or pressure ANC leaders to start talks. ``I support them fully but I think they should start talking now even if it means a program of talks about talks,'' he said. Earlier Sunday, Zambian state radio quoted Lusaka-based ANC secretary general Alfred Nzo as describing Mandela as ``the leader of the ANC and all the people of South Africa.'' Nzo called on all South Africans to support Mandela ``and join hands in efforts to bring about justice and democracy'' in their homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Former President, Readying to Testify In Iran-Contra Affair, Cancels Speech
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan, preparing to testify by videotape in the trial of a former White House aide, claimed a scheduling conflict Sunday in canceling a speech before thousands of auto dealers. Reagan's aides cited no specifics other than a schedule problem when they canceled the former president's appearance, said Mary Beth Robinson, spokeswoman for the National Automobile Dealers Association. Reagan's speech, which had been set for Tuesday, was to deliver the keynote address during the final session of the group's annual convention. NADA said Reagan would be replaced by three syndicated columnists _ Hugh Sidey, Mark Shields and James J. Kilpatrick. Defense attorneys for former National Security Adviser John Poindexter have subpoenaed Reagan's diaries for Poindexter's trial on charges of obstructing Congress during an investigation into arms sales to Contra forces in Nicaragua. A federal judge ordered Reagan to turn over some of the entries. Reagan is resisting the subpoena by invoking executive privilege. On Friday, Reagan agreed to answer questions in videotape testimony. That taping is to take place in Los Angeles on Friday, four days before the scheduled start of Poindexter's trial.

DOC.HEAD: Feuds Among Black Factions Pose Dilemma For Mandela
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with 12 killed in Natal Province Sunday, INSERT graf after 6th graf pvs, `The most ....' Pickup 7th graf pvs, `Buthelezi depicts...'
DOC.TEXT: Although most South African blacks are jubilant over Nelson Mandela's release, his African National Congress movement remains locked in bitter feuds with major black factions to its left and right. Mandela himself is so revered that no black leader has said a bad word about him in public. Yet the ANC, in whose name Mandela endured more than 27 years in prison, is considered by some black-consciousness militants to be a sellout, and by some black conservatives to be a power-hungry, Marxist-influenced party. Within South Africa, black youths who have grown up with such slogans as ``Freedom or death'' and waged street battles with police may have trouble accepting the idea that talks have precedence over armed struggle. ``For many of the youths, the struggle has simply meant to shoot your way to Pretoria,'' anti-apartheid leader Murphy Morobe said recently. The most influential of the ANC's black critics is Mangosuthu Buthelezi, chief minister of the KwaZulu homeland and leader of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization that claims 1.5 million members. More than 2,500 blacks have died in a three-year power struggle between Inkatha and ANC supporters in Natal Province. Police said 12 blacks were killed in factional fighting in the province on Sunday. Buthelezi depicts himself as a long-time foe of apartheid and an old friend of Mandela, but he contends the ANC is unjustifiably trying to claim the role as principal negotiator for the black community. ``It was Inkatha's refusal to be co-opted into the ANC and its refusal to become a subservient bag-carrier to the ANC that led to the two organizations being in conflict,'' Buthelezi said after Mandela's release was announced. ``There will be a conference table searching for the formula for a multiparty democracy,'' Buthelezi added. ``Mandela will be there. I will be there, the ANC will be there, Inkatha will be there.'' Buthelezi said Mandela, more than any other black leader, has the potential to put partisan interests aside and promote black unity. One faction that is unlikely to join in negotiations is the Pan Africanist Congress, which along with the ANC was banned in 1960 and legalized by President F.W. de Klerk earlier this month. The Pan Africanist Congress espouses black self-reliance and contends that whites play too large a role in ANC-aligned groups. It has criticized the ANC's increasing interest in negotiations, saying black-white talks should take place only when the government is ready to hand over political power and end white ownership of the bulk of the country's land. Even within the ranks of ANC supporters, there is some division. Commanders of its military wing reportedly were displeased last year as relatively moderate members of the exiled leadership raised the prospect of negotiations. Mandela has no formal position in the ANC at present, and his future role is uncertain. The organization's president, Oliver Tambo, is recovering from a stroke and possibly may be replaced later this year, but Mandela is not expected to take that post. He may find himself trying to balance his ANC duties with a broader role as leader of blacks across the political spectrum.

DOC.HEAD: Amid the Rejoicing, Worring Signs Emerge
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with further clashes and deaths, SUB 4th graf pvs, `In Cape...' with 4 grafs; pickup 5th graf pvs, `For some...'
DOC.TEXT: Amid the scenes of wild jubilation over the release of Nelson Mandela on Sunday, there were some ugly confrontations between jeering blacks and angry whites. Many whites looked worried or scared as they watched cheering and singing blacks surging through parts of central Johannesburg. Elegantly dressed whites shrank back as the black throngs danced around them. While most people, black and white, were well-behaved, a handful of blacks taunted whites, yelling ``Freedom is coming! Whites get out!'' A few furious whites lashed out, hurling bottles and insults at the blacks. In Cape Town, violence broke out about the time Mandela's motorcade arrived. Police said a black looter was shot to death by officers, and first-aid workers said more than 100 people were injured when riot police fired shotguns after black youths smashed shop windows. Some youths retaliated by hurling bottles. Clashes between police and celebrating blacks were reported in at least two other areas, including the tribal homeland of Ciskei, where hospital officials said police shot three people to death and wounded 20. Police said 12 people were killed in Natal Province in factional fighting between ANC supporters and backers of a more conservative black group. For some South Africans, the scattered incidents of racial tension were worrying signs of what might happen in the days ahead when the government and anti-apartheid groups attempt to negotiate over ending white rule. Many people in the crowds spoke of the need for peace and understanding between the races. At the elegant Carlton shopping mall, three young black men surrounded a young white couple, spitting on the frightened pair and shaking fists at them. Other blacks intervened and chased the taunters away. As blacks early Sunday surged through Hillbrow, near the city center, some whites in apartments overlooking the street hurled empty bottles at the celebrants. The marchers screamed insults and shook their fists, but no injuries were seen. Frightened white motorists caught in the milling masses in the streets leaned on their horns or scattered the crowds by driving at high speed. Some clenched their fists in revolutionary salutes in apparent attempts to placate hooting blacks. A white man watching the celebrants from his doorstep said, ``Look at them, look at them. What is happening to South Africa?'' Some black youths pretended to fire imaginary machine guns at police vans filled with white officers shadowing the celebrants. Other blacks ran up to the vans, yelling ``Get out! Get out!'' But much larger groups of blacks shouted ``Peace! Peace! Peace!'' Most blacks and whites spoke of the need to solve South Africa's problems peacefully. ``I pray to God we have peace in South Africa,'' one black marcher said. ``We must all live together.'' Leaders on both sides have expressed fears that white and black extremists will provoke violence in the months ahead to try to derail negotiations for their own ends. White extremists demand the retention of white supremacy; some black militants oppose a compromise with whites. ``I fear what is coming. It will be a terrible time, but we must overcome it by working together,'' said the Rev. Allan Boesak, a top anti-apartheid leader.

DOC.HEAD: What a Fight! No Winner, No Loser, And a Long Count Furor
LaserPhotos TOK5,9,10,13,14 LaserColor TOK11
DOC.TEXT: Buster Douglas, a 29-year-old boxer from Columbus, Ohio, knocked out Mike Tyson on Sunday in a world championship heavyweight bout with no winner, no loser and a ``long count'' controversy. What a fight! Hours after underdog Douglas' 10th-round knockout, the World Boxing Council and World Boxing Association suspended the result pending investigation of a ``long count'' protest by Tyson's promoter, Don King. Tyson, knocked out for the first time in his pro career, said he's still the champion. ``I knocked him out before he knocked me out,'' Tyson said. Douglas said he's champ: ``Just call it a victory for the small man.'' Douglas' father, former middleweight world contender Bill ``Dynamite'' Douglas, said: ``He pulled the greatest upset in history.'' Because of an error by referee Octavio Meyran, Douglas was on the canvas for 12 seconds after Tyson knocked him down in the eighth round. Two rounds later, Douglas knocked out Tyson with a five-punch combination. ``There is no champion before Feb. 20,'' when the WBC meets in Mexico City to settle the controversy, said WBC president Jose Sulaiman of Mexico. Sulaiman suggested what course the two governing bodies might take: ``When there are problems, a rematch is absolutely mandatory,'' he said. Only the International Boxing Federation, which sanctioned the bout as a championship match, said Douglas is the winner. The IBF, however, isn't recognized by the Japan Boxing Commission. Douglas' disputed victory has created a wide-open heavyweight division that for three years had been the personal domain of Tyson, who was 37-0 with 33 knockouts. Tyson was scheduled to defend the title against No. 1 contender Evander Holyfield on June 18 at Atlantic City, N.J., but Holyfield has no contractual obligation to fight Tyson if Tyson is not the heavyweight champion. ``There's nothing wrong with losing, I can handle a loss, but I want to lose fairly,'' Tyson said at the post-fight news conference, which Douglas did not attend. Douglas was felled in the eighth round by a right uppercut to the jaw. ``I wasn't really hurt,'' Douglas said. ``When I looked up the count was at six. I got up between seven and eight. I clearly heard eight.'' Douglas was upright at nine, but by then the timekeeper had tolled 10, although Meyran _ who failed to pick up the timekeeper's count _ didn't know that. He motioned for the two boxers to resume fighting, then the bell rang. Contrary to the old saying, the bell cannot save a fighter. It isn't rung if a fighter is down past the three-minute limit of the round, but rings if a fighter beats the 10-count. Douglas hurt Tyson three or four times in the ninth round, and by the end of the round, Tyson's left eye was closed. Just past the minute mark of the 10th round, Douglas landed a five-punch combination, with the key blows being a right uppercut, a left and a right to the jaw _ and Tyson went down and was counted out. The most famous long count in boxing history took place in a bout between Jack Dempsey and Gene Tunney on Sept. 22, 1927, at Chicago's Soldier Field before nearly 150,000 fans and a radio audience of 50 million. The newly adopted knockdown rule required the standing fighter to go to the farthest neutral corner before the count would start. After six rounds, Dempsey, seeking to regain the title he lost to Tunney a year earlier, toppled his opponent with a barrage of punches but went to the wrong corner, using up five seconds before he moved to the proper corner. Fourteen seconds later, Tunny got up and went on to win a unanimous decision for the 10-round fight. Said Dempsey: ``I was robbed.''

DOC.HEAD: Violence Turns Mandela Welcoming to Chaos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story listed on AM-Digest as AM-SAfrica-Celebration
DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
LaserPhoto CPN19
DOC.TEXT: Confrontations between young blacks and white policemen turned celebration to chaos Sunday at the welcoming rally for Nelson Mandela on his first day of freedom. Tens of thousands had gathered hours before, hoping for a glimpse of the black leader, who was released after 27 years in jail for fighting the white-minority government. But as the sun set, cheers of ``Viva Mandela'' and the energetic singing of the morning faded to new sounds. People heard shotgun fire, police helicopters crisscrossing the sky, wailing ambulances, barking police dogs, and chanting black youths, pounding their feet and issuing angry challenges. Police said officers fatally shot a black looter, and first-aid workers said at least 100 people were injured when riot police fired shotguns after groups of black youths smashed shop windows. The center of the city, called ``the fairest Cape,'' was a battlefield. Thousands of blacks and whites stood in the huge parade ground, their eyes fixed on the City Hall balcony as they listened to endless political speeches over defective loudspeakers and waited for Mandela to appear. They waited, even though they could hear, at the edges of the throng, the shattering shop windows, the intermittent gunshots. As the 71-year-old prisoner, free for just two hours, was driven in a motorcade past streets lined with tens of thousands of people, the first shots rang out near the railway station. Bands of youths had broken shop windows earlier in the day, and police who came to investigate were taunted by a crowd that outnumbered them six to one. They guarded the shop but did not draw their guns. But later, when people began shattering the outer windows of a shopping plaza across the street from the parade ground, four policemen appeared in the middle of the street and began firing shotguns at the black youths. The boys fought back, hurling broken bottles that soon made a shard-covered no-man's land. The youths stood on the edge of the crowd, or hid behind cars and buildings, with makeshift wooden and metal weapons. Many tried to blend in or stand in front of the bystanders. On a side street, women and children watched a momentary standoff. Suddenly, a blue-uniformed officer wheeled, aimed his shotgun toward the crowd and fired three times. Some of the onlookers screamed and ran, but most fell to the pavement. Some tried to hide behind a car, but the driver drove away. As the terrified women looked up to see why they had been made targets, they saw thin, young boys, in dirty T-shirts and shorts, scamper past them, laughing. But there were peacemakers on both sides. Ordinary folk, black and white, formed a human chain around a makeshift first-aid center in the street near city hall. Each time shots rang out, they crouched to the ground, but they never broke their lines. When hooligans smashed into Indian-owned snack shops on the edge of the parade ground, a young black man raised the ANC flag to protect the white policemen who came to stand guard in front of the shops. The young man's colleagues formed a wall with their bodies to hold back scores of young radicals who wanted to get at the officer.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Gives Moral Support To Opposition, Gentle Warning To Government
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III Sunday gave moral support to opposition parties and a gentle warning to the interim government, which has been accused of trying to consolidate power prior to elections. During a 4{-hour stopover in Bucharest, he succeeded in underlining America's commitment to free and fair elections without unduly alienating government leaders who have been strongly criticized by the opposition. Less than two weeks ago, the United States criticized the National Salvation Front government, which took power after the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, for attempting to impede opposition parties contesting the May 20 general election. Baker did applaud ``the reform movement'' in Romania since Ceausescu's overthrow and execution, but he didn't praise the government. Premier Petre Roman said ``an endorsement would be very good, but ... '' Baker said he told interim President Ion Iliescu and Roman that ``the betterment of relations of the United States with Romania will depend on fully free, fair elections and the respect for human rights and the rights of minorities.'' Baker also announced that the United States will offer Romania $80 million in food assistance. A State Department official said it will include 550,000 tons of feed grain and 8,200 tons of butter. The Romanian government previously had complained that the United States had not fulfilled a promise to send aid following the revolution. Opposition leaders told Baker they were still being intimidated by the government, said Corneliu Coposu, president of the National Peasant Party, the country's largest opposition group. ``The collective atmosphere was that there is fear, and it is a sustained action of fear,'' Coposu said. The Front's decision to participate in the election, reversing an earlier pledge to stay out, sparked mass demonstrations by students and opponents who demanded it resign. In a compromise, the Front agreed to share power in a new Provisional Council of National Unity, which was inaugurated Friday to run the country until the election. But many of the 17 opposition party leaders and student representatives who met Baker said they told him the Front was trying to control the ruling council and continue the old Communist system under a new guise. ``In Romania the youth made its revolution, and Iliescu and his friends have monopolized the revolution,'' said Nica Leon, president of the Liberal Democratic Party. Toma George Maiorescu, president of the Romanian Ecological Movement, said the parties also told Baker that elections should be postponed at least until September. Iliescu called his meeting with Baker ``positive'' and said the secretary of state had reaffirmed U.S. willingness to ``meet halfway'' Romania's new openness. Roman said he viewed Baker's visit ``as the beginning of a new relationship on a new basis, taking into account the new democracy. ... From now on, we can speak of American aid as not just humanitarian, I mean aid to rebuild.'' But Baker was noncommital on the question of economic aid or restoring Romania's favored-nation trading status. Several opposition parties told him the United States should wait until after the election before it makes a decision.

DOC.HEAD: Class Action Sought for Pipeline Workers
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit filed on behalf of a carpenter seeking a pension for work on the Alaska pipeline eventually could include up to 23,000 union members as plaintiffs, a lawyer said. The lawsuit was filed Friday in U.S. District Court in Portland against the Northern Alaska Carpenters Retirement Fund by Daniel Duncan, a carpenter from Medford who was disabled while working on the pipeline. Duncan claims carpenters were wrongly deprived of retirement money when the fund's trustee forfeited their contributions. Duncan claims in the lawsuit that the trustee refused to vest carpenters with less than 10 years service who were laid off as the oil pipeline project neared completion in the late 1970s. The lawsuit seeks certification from the court to add as plaintiffs as many as 3,000 other carpenters who worked on the pipeline between Dec. 31, 1972, and Jan. 1, 1980. Richard J. Birmingham, one of Duncan's attorneys, said Friday that the lawsuit also could apply to 20,000 other union members, including Teamsters, and total retirement claims could run as high as $50 million. William Earhart, whose Portland company administers the carpenters' retirement fund, said Friday he had no comment on the lawsuit. Duncan alleges in his lawsuit that the carpenters' union was ``partially terminated'' under federal law when the layoffs reached significant portions of the membership. Under the law, the lawsuit says, non-vested union members automatically become vested in their retirement fund when partial termination occurs. The lawsuit says a rider attached to a budget bill in 1984 by Alaska's two senators unconstitutionally denied union members the protection of the doctrine of partial termination. The lawsuit asks that the Northern Alaska Carpenters Retirement Fund be required to vest class members. It seeks to have the fund enjoined from liquidating or distributing trust funds so as to prevent payment of the accrued benefits. It also asks that class members be paid their accrued benefits as damages and seeks attorneys' fees.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Praise Mandela's Release, Urge More Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Bush telephoning Mandela, comment from Zambian President Kaunda, Lech Walesa, Natan Sharansky, other U.S. reaction; EDITS to TRIM. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's emergence Sunday from nearly three decades in prison brought praise from world leaders, but the international rejoicing was tempered by appeals for swifter progress toward ending apartheid. As Mandela, 71, walked from the grounds of his prison outside Cape Town into crowds of supporters who had campaigned ceaselessly for his release, the African National Congress welcomed him ``to the warm embrace of our people and the national liberation movement.'' President Bush said he telephoned Mandela, told him all Americans ``were rejoicing at his release'' and invited him to the White House. ``I stated to him our desire to see a peaceful evolution towards a totally racially free South Africa, a society without prejudice, a society of total freedom,'' Bush told reporters in the Rose Garden. In Atlanta, Coretta Scott King, widow of slain U.S. civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., said she was overjoyed by the release of Mandela, ``who has shown us the tremendous power of unearned suffering for a just cause.'' Special church services were scheduled in many U.S. cities. India's Prime Minister V.P. Singh called Mandela a ``valiant soldier of independence, justice and equality,'' and French Premier Michel Rocard invited him to visit Paris. Gabon's chief of state urged other African nations to restore diplomatic ties with South Africa, and Britain said it was time to reconsider international sanctions. Anti-apartheid campaigners took to the streets to celebrate, including thousands who thronged to London's Trafalgar Square, singing, dancing and waving flags of the newly legalized ANC. Mandela's release provided a ``surge of hope'' that should be harnessed to open talks between the government and the black majority, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said. Hurd's deputy, Foreign Minister William Waldegrave, called Mandela ``a leader of real stature to represent the Africans who can enter into dialogue.'' Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda called for the ANC to suspend guerrilla actions in South Africa but to maintain its military capability in case of violence by right-wing extremists. ``The time for talking has come,'' said Kaunda, whose country plays host to the ANC's exile headquarters and guerrilla bases. But the ANC said in a statement released in Harare, Zimbabwe, that it was not prepared to open talks with the white-minority government of President F.W. de Klerk until he lifted the state of emergency, released all political prisoners, and repealed laws that formed the basis of the apartheid system of segregation. Mandela reiterated those conditions at a rally Sunday. The Nigerian government called Mandela's release ``positive proof'' that international sanctions have worked, but Britain said it would contact the European Community and the Commonwealth of former colonies about encouraging new ties with South Africa. ``When people are doing the right thing boldly and courageously as President de Klerk is it seems quite absurd to still use sticks to beat them with, however small those sticks may be,'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said. ``The die is now cast. The way is open for peaceable negotiations. What is the use of trying to hit out? Why not help the process.'' Canadian sanctions will remain in effect until apartheid is scrapped, Foreign Minister Joe Clark said. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney wrote a letter to Mandela, saying, ``We celebrate with the world that your freedom from prison today may soon lead to the freedom of all South Africans from the injustice of apartheid.'' Sweden, which maintained strong economic sanctions against South Africa, said Mandela's release creates new hope for democracy and freedom. ``Through his courage, commitment and moral strength, he has been a constant source of inspiration for those who hold the ideals of freedom, democracy and fairness high,'' Swedish Premier Ingvar Carlsson said on Mandela. In Poland, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa called Mandela a man who devoted his life to the realization of the idea of equality of all people. ``Experiences of recent months show that there is no room in the world any more for regimes which hold human rights in contempt,'' Walesa said in Warsaw. Australia's Prime Minister Bob Hawke described Mandela's release as the most positive sign the world had seen that ``the walls of the abhorrent apartheid system may soon be breached.'' Hawke and Spain's Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez also urged the South African government to build on the good will flowing from Mandela's release. President Mario Soares of Portugal said he was ``deeply satisfied with this, the latest significant step in the democratic reforms currently going on in South Africa.'' In Italy, Premier Giulio Andreotti welcomed the ``gesture capable of giving a fundamental impetus to dialogue between all South Africans.'' Israel welcomed the South African government's move as a step toward improving relations between the two countries. Human rights activist Natan Sharansky, who emigrated to Israel after spending nine years in Soviet prisons and labor camps, said he was glad Mandela was released and hoped ``the years in prison have changed this leader, that he is now more tolerant and is ready for a dialogue.'' Japan's Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said he hoped Mandela would play a major role in national reconciliation in South Africa, and Jordan's Minister of Information Ibrahim Izzeddine agreed: ``It's a great moment to see a national leader who has suffered for 27 years go free and have the chance to lead his country to freedom. ... It's a great moment in the history of mankind.'' Thousands of well-wishers gathered for a street party outside the South African Embassy overlooking London's Trafalgar Square, where anti-apartheid protesters have stage a round-the-clock picket since April 19, 1986, demanding Mandela's release. Busloads of police officers stood by, but the crowd was good-natured, waving ANC flags, singing and dancing. A banner was placed at the foot of Admiral Nelson's column in the center of the square, temporarily renaming it ``Mandela's Column.'' Elsewhere in Britain, church bells pealed when Mandela was released, and a vigil was held at northern England's York Minster cathedral.

DOC.HEAD: Heeeeeeeeears Kermit
DOC.TEXT: It took two takes, but President Bush did the honors Sunday night introducing a White House television special honoring literacy teachers and adults who learned to read late in life. The East Room of the White House was transformed into a studio for the taping of the National Literacy Honors Gala, which featured walk-on appearances by such stars as Jamie Lee Curtis, Barbara Mandrell, Anita Baker, Patrick Swayze and Kermit the Frog. Bush and his wife Barbara, a longtime crusader on behalf of literacy causes, presented awards to three literacy teachers and three adult learners. The president had to redo his two-minute opening at the end of the show, which will be aired on ABC Television as a prime-time special sometime in March. An embarrassed producer announced at the end of the hour-long taping that because of a glitch, the cameras had not been rolling during Bush's first try. ``A wireless mike antenna fell. It hit a lighting cable and it grounded the whole thing out,'' a sound man explained afterwards. The award recipients were instructed to take their medallions off ``because we're back at the top of the show.'' Bush good-naturedly did his remarks all over again. After finishing, he laughed and said, ``Show biz! Is that it?'' Swayze, of ``Dirty Dancing'' fame, also repeated his remarks. ``Literacy is critical to our very future .... essential to our freedom,'' Bush said. Many in the East Room audience of 200 were moved to tears by taped footage of the three adults who spoke of their problems as illiterates and how they overcame them. They were: James Underwood, 49, of Charlotte, N.C., who now runs a $300,000-a-year cleaning business; Inez Cortiz, 30, of Nicholson, Pa., an ex-welfare mother now training to be a nurse, and Ed Castor, 47, of Windfall, Ind., who learne to read after technology made his old factory job obsolete. Also honored were three teachers, Lorna Anderson, 57, of Park Forest, Ill., Arthur Strope, 65, of Stuart, Fla., and Evangeline Olea, 43, of Phoenix. Publisher Harold McGraw Jr. and Wally ``Famous'' Amos, the cookie entrepreneur, were honored for leadership in the literacy movement. Bush voiced the hope that the tales would inspire ``millions'' more people to seek help. Illiteracy is a problem that runs ``from the most personal and private pain to the broadest national distress, from those who will never know that a book can be a friend in the still hours of the night, to those who do not even have the skills to get a job or be an active citizen,'' he said. It figures in ``every human and social concern: labor lost, potential unfulfilled, poverty, bigotry and despair.'' ABC Television has not yet selected a date for the airing of the special.

DOC.HEAD: Says Soviet Jewish Influx Jeopardizes Peace Efforts; Condemns Bus Attack
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat said Sunday the growing controversy over Soviet-Jewish emigration to Israel will jeopardize efforts for a peaceful settlement to the Arab-Israeli conflict. Arafat appealed to the Soviet Union to rescind an agreement with Israel for direct flights between Moscow and Tel-Aviv for immigrants, and he urged Arab leaders to convene an emergency Arab summit. Moscow already has suspended the flight agreement. Speaking at a news conference, Arafat also accused Israeli soldiers of killing at least four Palestinians in the Gaza Strip town from which a bus filled with Israeli tourists left before it was attacked in the Egyptian desert last week. He rejected reports linking the Palestine Liberation Organization or other Palestinian groups with last Sunday's attack 40 miles northeast of Cairo. Nine Israelis were killed in the ambush. ``The attack must have been carried out by extremists whatever their color, identity or nationality is,'' he said at a news conference in Baghdad, where the PLO has offices and its official radio station, Voice of Palestine. In a published interview, Arafat appeared to condemn the attack. ``Of course we were surprised by the attack, because we reject aggression on any civilians, be they Jewish, American or European,'' Monday's issue of the London-based magazine Arab Jerusalem quoted him as saying. But Arafat said the longer the United States and Israel avoid a comprehensive peace settlement, ``the larger the possibility of an explosion in the region.'' Cairo's relations with the PLO have been strained over the bus attack, with columnists in government-run newspapers condemning Arafat by name for not speaking out against it. News reports have said those involved were Palestinian. At the news conference, Arafat said the recent influx of Soviet Jews to Israel was made possible because of an understanding between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their December summit in Malta. ``It is regrettable to say that this part of the accord was made in Malta after President Bush insisted that the Soviets open a direct route to Israel,'' he said. Arafat said an Arab League delegation will visit Moscow later this month to ask the Kremlin to halt the exodus permanently. Arafat declined to say if the Soviet Union promised to take any steps last week during talks between a Soviet envoy and PLO leaders in Tunis, but that the PLO has ongoing contacts with Moscow on the issue. The leader of a radical PLO faction, Nayef Hawatmeh, secretary-general of the Marxist-oriented Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, claimed Feb. 3 that Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Gennady Tarassov made such a promise in Tunis. Arafat said the Israeli army has launched massive raids against the Palestinian residents of Rafah since Thursday, after reports alleged that the bus attack was planned and executed by residents of the Mediterranean town in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. Arafat said at least four Palestinians were killed and 331 wounded in Rafah since the Israeli army began the alleged offensive. ``I appeal to the world community to halt this massacre immediately,'' he said. There was no independent confirmation of his allegations, but one Palestinian was shot dead in Rafah and 52 suffered gunshot wounds in the city since the bus attack, Arab reports and hospital officials say. Most of the casualties resulted from three days of protests following Wednesday's fatal shooting of a Palestinian teen-ager during a stone-throwing clash. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said Sunday the bus attack was planned by two Palestinian deportees. Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said in a speech in Tel Aviv the attack was carried out by what he called the ``Palestinian wing of the Islamic Jihad group,'' Israel's national news agency Itim said. No further details were given. Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 655 Palestinians in the 26-month-old uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 181 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators, while 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: State-Run TV Gives Extensive Coverage To Mandela Release
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government television broadcast Nelson Mandela's release from prison live Sunday and later showed the speech in which he endorsed armed struggle against the government. Customarily, the South African Broadcasting Corp. offers live news coverage only of well-controlled events such as a presidential seech. But the company scrapped the heart of its afternoon programming Sunday to show Mandela's walk to freedom, even though the event occurred 75 minutes behind schedule. In the interim, SABC reporter Clarence Keyter became caught up in the excitement of the moment, repeatedly telling viewers they were about to watch history in the making. ``This is the moment the world has been waiting for,'' Keyter said. ``The sun is shining on South Africa.'' The coverage stopped when Mandela's motorcade pulled away from Victor Verster prison en route to Cape Town, and there was no live coverage of later violence in the city or of Mandela's speech at City Hall. But the main 8 p.m. news program devoted an entire hour to the release, showing footage of black youths looting shops and broadcasting on a delayed basis virtually all of Mandela's speech. Prior to Feb. 2, when President F.W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC, the speech would have been illegal and the SABC could have been prosecuted for broadcasting it. But on Sunday, as Keyter and Mandela both said, a new South Africa was in the making.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Becomes Chief of African Tribal Clan
DOC.TEXT: Moses B. Anderson is one of 13 black Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, but the multicolored, braided rope about his neck makes him unique. He's chief of an African tribal clan. The Motor City's 61-year-old auxiliary bishop last month became chief of the Aduana clan of West Africa's Ashanti tribe in Ghana. With the title came the symbolic braid and a new name: Nana Kwasi Amoateng I. ``I won't be able to live there but I intend to do as much as I can for the village (of Antoa),'' Anderson said. ``I am in more of a position now to get more African-Americans involved with Africa.'' Last month, about 1,000 Ashanti gathered in Antoa for Anderson's installation as the clan's first-ever chief. Before the tribe's centuries-old ceremony, the bishop had to buy a ceremonial sword, umbrella and sandals. ``Chiefs may never be seen barefoot and their feet can never touch the ground, so they must always wear sandals,'' Anderson said. ``They must always be seen clothed and they can never sit on the ground. That's why stools or chairs are so important. It is a symbol of dignity to sit. It is a symbol of dignity to be sheltered by an umbrella.'' Anderson's new role is based on Ashanti culture, not the tribal religion, so there is no conflict with his Catholic duties. Anderson said Cardinal Edmund Szoka, who heads the Detroit Archdiocese until he moves to a Vatican post in June, is supportive of his new role. ``He said, `Well, now remember that you're still a Catholic bishop.' He was just joking. He's really interested in knowing what all this means for black Catholics in Detroit and around the country,'' Anderson said. The cleric said he already has started work on helping the 500-member village. Anderson said he plans to collect items such as ballpoint pens, chalk, paper and clothing. He said he also hopes to raise money to help buy a computer for Bishop Peter Sarpong of the Kumasi Diocese, who in 1987 suggested Anderson become a chief. ``They invited me in 1988 for the ceremony, but that was at the same time of the church closings and I wanted to stay here to be supportive of the cardinal,'' Anderson said, referring to Szoka's consolidation plan which closed 35 churches in the archdiocese. Anderson said he now tells people he is a Ghanian-American, rather than African-American.

DOC.HEAD: Did Abe Lincoln Visit Cape May?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to ADD that Monday is Lincoln's birthday.
DOC.TEXT: Seven score and one year ago, the A. Lincoln who visited this seashore town may have been just a grocer from Philadelphia. But some residents continue to insist it was the future 16th president who stayed in a hotel in this resort community on July 31, 1849. Those who dispute the tale say Lincoln, whose birthday comes Monday, was in Springfield, Ill., practicing law that long-ago July 31, winning a judgment of $112.30 for a client. Casting further doubt is a record of an Abel Lincoln, a Philadelphia grocer who they say may have headed to the Jersey shore that summer day. ``All these years, we may have been honoring a grocer,'' said Jake Schaad, who has researched the story and is writing a book about the history of Cape May. One version of the story claims that, while in Cape May, Lincoln rejected an offer to become governor of the Oregon Territory after his wife, Mary Todd Lincoln, told him she was afraid of Indians, Schaad said. ``It's a good story but it didn't happen,'' Schaad said, adding that other versions have Lincoln fathering an illegitimate son while at the shore. The town claims to be America's oldest seashore resort, tracing its visitors to just after the Revolutionary War, said Jeffrey Dorwart, a history professor at Rutgers University-Camden who is researching a book for Cape May County's 300th anniversary in 1992. Some long-time residents knew Henry Irick, who said that when he was 16 he came with his father and Lincoln to this community of Victorian homes and lazy sea breezes. Mary Ann Nyblade, a 65-year-old Cape May resident who can trace her family in the town back to 1695, said she still clings to Irick's story. Irick was the son of John S. Irick, a wealthy Vincentown farmer who supposedly met up with Lincoln and came to the Mansion House in Cape May. He recalled that visit in a newspaper interview in the late 1890s and the story was born, Ms. Nyblade said. The Mansion House guest register shows an A. Lincoln and wife from Philadelphia in Room 24. Fire destroyed the hotel in 1856 but the register was saved, Ms. Nyblade said. She acknowledged that the reference to Philadelphia on the register was a problem for the future-president theorists, but say the future president may have listed Philadelphia if they had taken the steamboat from there to Cape May. The man who saved that register was Lewis Stevens, and the 250-page book is now in Huntsville, Ala., in a safe-deposit box owned by Bill Stevens, Ms. Nyblade's nephew and a descendant of Lewis Stevens. Bill Stevens said in a telephone interview that the register contains signatures of other famous people such as Sen. Henry Clay. However, he said he has learned too much about Lincoln to believe he could have visited Cape May. ``I'm convinced he was not in Cape May at that time,'' he said. There's no doubt about that, said Thomas F. Schwartz, curator of the Lincoln collection at the Illinois State Historical Library in Springfield. On July 31, Lincoln was at least 1,000 miles west of Cape May, filing an affidavit in Sangamon County Circuit Court for Henry Bailer, who was owed $111.75 by Oliver Davis. Davis ended up paying $112.30, which Schwartz guesses included interest. Dorwart said he can prove President Benjamin Harrison spent summers in Cape May, as did President U.S. Grant and Woodrow Wilson while he was governor of New Jersey. But Lincoln is a different story. ``My sense is that, since looking at the Lincoln papers, he was in Illinois,'' Dorwart said. He said residents of Cape May, 50 miles south of the Mason-Dixon Line and site of several duels between Northerners and Southerners in the 1840s and 1850s, may have been trying to prove their loyalty to the Union after the Civil War by circulating the story. Irick's tale probably cemented the story as fact, Dorwart said. The Cape May County Historical Museum still features a facsimile of the hotel register signature and everybody acknowledges that some legends just seem to die hard. ``Even if Lincoln didn't come down here, it's part of our culture that he was here,'' Dorwart said.

DOC.HEAD: Bradley Raises More than $4 Million toward 1990 Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: With more than $4.1 million in the bank for his 1990 Senate race, New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley again has demonstrated his prodigious power to draw money from a national pool although he deflects speculation about his presidential aspirations. Contributions of nearly $4.5 million flowed into the Bradley account in 1989, including $3.9 million from individuals, $570,475 from political action committees and $17,500 from the Democratic Party, Federal Election Commission records show. Dividends and interest on the money brought in nearly $200,000, according to the Democrat's 1989 campaign finance report. Bradley has picked up $9.45 million in contributions, interest and refunds since Jan. 1, 1985, including $8.9 million in contributions alone. Among senators facing the voters this year, he is second only to Sen. Phil Gramm, D-Texas, with $10.5 million in receipts, according to an analysis by Common Cause. Campaign manager Nick Donatiello says he expects to raise an additional $2 million, at least, to help buy expensive television advertising time in the New York and Philadelphia markets. Although the Bradley campaign organization is not yet working against any announced opponent _ New Jersey Republicans say they hope to announce a candidate by March _ it spent $2.79 million last year on operations, $1.8 million in the last six months, reports indicate. The senator maintains he is running for only one job: ``What I want to do is be a U.S. senator from New Jersey,'' he repeated last week. Bradley may not yet know whether 1992 will be his year to reach for the Democratic presidential nomination, but his statewide re-election effort has national overtones. _ Bradley paid more than $200,000 to Joe Peritz and Associates of Wilton, Conn., for polling. Although Donatiello insists the ``vast majority'' of those surveyed are from New Jersey, the senator said his campaign had been taking the national pulse on such issues as tax reform. That issue is close to Bradley's heart because he helped design 1986 tax reform legislation. _ His 1990 campaign has purchased about $500,000 in computer equipment to keep track of his 30,000 to 35,000 contributors around the country, including 7,000 new donors, according to Donatiello. _ In addition, the campaign has paid thousands of dollars for video screens to project Bradley's larger-than-life image across banquet halls at his fund-raisers. Expenditures from July to December also included $35,000 paid to a California media consultant, Michael Kaye and Associates, who has worked for Democratic Sens. Edward Kennedy and Alan Cranston. Kaye, who has worked with Bradley throughout his career, designed 30-second television spots that ran last summer on New Jersey's cable stations and were reintroduced last Monday. The latest cable spots carry no campaign message but feature Bradley chatting about such issues as clean drinking water and deterring youngsters from joining gangs. While he concentrates his public comments about the race on issues that affect New Jersey constituents, the senator's active fund-raising schedule has included a Boston event Sept. 25 that raised $100,000; a Los Angeles event Oct. 12 that raised $650,000; a Chicago event Nov. 6 that brought in $200,000; and a $1,000-a-person New Jersey fund-raiser Dec. 4 that brought in $500,000. The senator has been especially successful in California, where help from Michael Eisner, chief executive officer of Disney Studios, and Michael Ovitz, head of Creative Artists Agency, has brought dollars and attention from Hollywood's heavy hitters. Bradley's latest group of celebrity contributors include novelists Judith Krantz and Sidney Sheldon, ``Platoon'' and ``Wall Street'' screenwriter and producer Oliver Stone, sister gossip columnists Abigail Van Buren, known for her Dear Abby column and Eppie Lederer, known popularly as Ann Landers, and ``Tootsie'' and ``Out of Africa'' director and producer Sydney Pollack. Television gossip columnist Rona Barrett, former Eagles rock musician Don Henley, singer Neil Diamond, actress Sally Field and Motown Records founder Berry Gordy also fill the pages of Bradley's contributor list.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain Drenches Florida, Northwest Gets Cold
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain drenched southern Florida on Sunday, and light showers and snow fell in the Northwest, the Ohio Valley. Rain also fell in the lower Great Lakes region. Light snow fell on the upper Mississippi Valley, the upper Great Lakes and Maine. In the Northwest, a cold front prompted a snow advisory for parts of Montana and Washington. Up to a half-foot of snow was possible in mountain passes, the National Weather Service said. Temperatures were expected to plunge in Washington and other northwestern states. Cold arctic air brought rain to Washington and Oregon. Astoria, Ore., received a half-inch of rain in six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST. Sunny skies prevailed from the southern and central High Plains to Georgia and the Carolinas after severe thunderstorms battered parts of the Southeast with tornadoes and high winds Saturday, killing four people and injuring dozens. Skies were also sunny across much of New England. The cold spot in the Lower 48 states was International Falls, Minn., where the morning low was minus 7 degrees. Mountain highways were reopened and the threat of flooding eased on southwest Washington rivers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Telephones Mandela
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 30th graf, ``The other conditions xxx to eliminate redundant condition
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned Nelson Mandela from the White House on Sunday, told him all Americans ``were rejoicing at his release'' after 27 years in South Africa's prisons and personally invited him to the White House. ``I stated to him our desire to see a peaceful evolution towards a totally racially free South Africa, a society without prejudice, a society of total freedom,'' Bush told reporters in the Rose Garden late Sunday afternoon. ``He told me that he wanted to consult some of his colleagues, but that he expected he would be able to accept my invitation,'' the president said. ``I told him that all Americans were delighted after these many years in jail that he was released, that we were rejoicing at his release,'' said Bush. ``It was a very friendly conversation. It lasted five or six minutes, maybe, and he expressed his gratitude to me and to the American people for calling,'' said Bush. The president said the future of U.S. sanctions against the white minority government of South Africa was not discussed during his brief conversation with the African National Congress leader. ``That did not come up. I will address that at an appropriate time. There's no time frame. I will be discussing that with our top advisers,'' said Bush, who on Saturday called South African President F.W. de Klerk and invited him to pay a separate visit to Washington. ``I'm not prepared to express my view on sanctions at this time. We've had some momentous events, and I think the thing is to let these events settle in now,'' said Bush. ``There's differences of opinion in the Congress ... (and) American public opinion. Let's just rejoice in the fact that Mr. de Klerk took some very forward steps and let us rejoice in the fact that Mr. Mandela is free.'' Asked whether he planned to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to South Africa now, Bush said, ``I have no immediate plans to do that,'' but said he would not rule it out. Bush, asked whether he plans a more active U.S. role in seeking a peaceful solution to the problems in South Africa, said: ``Anytime that human rights and equality are at stake anywhere in the world, the United States has a very useful role to play, and I think both President de Klerk and Mr. Mandela feel that way. Indeed, both of them indicated that to me. ``We have had a cutoff of high level visits for some time, but now with the freeing of Mandela it is appropriate that high-level visits take place,'' said Bush, who added that he is ``sure they'll be separate'' visits. He said Mandela ``sounded restrained'' in their telephone conversation. ``His comments were very warm and very _ I don't want to use the word appreciative _ but I think he was glad that I called. There was a calmness in his voice. And he, all in all, I'm sure, enjoyed this first day very, very much. Although he didn't state that ... you could just sense it from the way in which he expressed himself.'' Bush said he expects a de Klerk visit to draw criticism. ``I've invited Mr. de Klerk to the White House. I think the world rejoices in the fact that Mr. Mandela is free. And there's always going to be somebody shooting at Mr. de Klerk's decision or something of that nature, or maybe mine. But I've invited him here. I hope he comes here. I have invited Mr. Mandela here. I hope he comes here. ... That's the way it is. That's the way it is going to be. ``There's always somebody out on the fringe somewhere trying to assign an unhelpful motive. I think Mr. de Klerk in making certain changes inside South Africa, has done something that many of us felt was long overdue, but nevertheless he's done it. ... He deserves credit for that,'' said Bush. The U.S. sanctions include a ban on new investment in South Africa, a prohibition on the import of certain South African products and the cancellation of landing rights for South African airlines. Asked whether he felt the sanctions had prompted de Klerk's decision, Bush said, ``Maybe so. I don't know.'' Even as Mandela walked to freedom Sunday, the debate was already joined in the United States over whether to lift the sanctions. ``It was wonderful to see that man walk out of that prison,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. ``The struggle of apartheid is not a struggle of black against white. It is a struggle of democracy.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., speaking on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' said, ``It's time for us to begin discussing in our country, between the president and the Congress, as to when the sanctions would end and which ones would end. We certainly need to acknowledge these events. We certainly need to encourage the South African government to go forward.'' But Rep. William H. Gray, D-Pa., the House majority whip, said, ``Although we welcome (the freeing of Mandela) and we applaud the move by Mr. de Klerk, the fact is that South Africa is still not free. The future is really in their hands. ... Whether or not sanctions are lifted really is up to the de Klerk government.'' Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation, that ``if you get an equitable situation based on negotiations where everybody gives a little and everyone ends up as a winner, I think you can have a lot better South Africa.'' South Africa's minority white population of 5 million has maintained control through its apartheid laws and denial of political rights to the 26 million black residents. Cohen said, ``The last thing the American government should be doing is prescribing the type of constitutional change that we want to see.'' Asked whether the United States backs the principal of one man, one vote, the State Department official replied, ``We believe in universal suffrage. And if you have one man, one vote, in every democratic system in the world, there are limitations on pure majority rule.'' He called Bush's invitation to de Klerk ``a tremendous symbolic gesture.'' Bush ``would be the first person to say that apartheid is not over. It's just the beginning of a process right now, and we certainly wouldn't want to eliminate all of our leverage in that situation,'' Cohen said. ``But I think the time has now come to make a gesture which, in effect, says, `You're making progress,''' said Cohen. Gray said the Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986 _ passed over the veto of then-President Reagan _ spelled out that before sanctions could be lifted, South Africa had to free Mandela and all other political prisoners and meet at least three of four other criteria. De Klerk has already met one of the conditions by legalizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. The other conditions include an agreement by the government to engage in good faith negotiations on South Africa's political future, the lifting of the state of emergency, and making substantial progress toward dismantling apartheid. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., the Senate majority whip, said, ``Mandela is free, but black Africa still groans under the yoke of apartheid. The United States should keep up the pressure of sanctions, which undoubtedly have worked well, until the last vestige of apartheid is eradicated.'' The White House said Feb. 1 that Mandela would be invited to come at his convenience upon his release from prison after 27 years. Bush had already signalled more than a week ago that he would invite both Mandela and de Klerk to the White House for separate visits. John Herrick, a spokesman, said that in Saturday's phone call Bush ``expressed his admiration for the significant initiatives announced by the South African government in recent days and reiterated his hope there would be continued progress toward a negotiated solution in an atmosphere of nonviolence.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demand Ouster of Personalities from State-Run Television
With AM-Baker-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 people protested outside the government's television building Sunday, demanding the ouster of journalists they said were loyalists of toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. A dozen tanks and armored personnel carriers held back the demonstrators outside the building, where during the December revolution the new government's leaders took refuge while the army fought off Ceausescu's secret police. It was one of several protests, some involving tens of thousands of people, held by various groups over the weekend that are demanding an end to what they consider unfair policies that remain from the days of the executed hard-liner. Also Sunday, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker visited for several hours with government and opposition leaders. He withheld praise for the government and listened to opposition complaints. The demonstrators outside the TV headquarters accused the ruling National Salvation Front of controlling the mass media with Ceausescu loyalists. They chanted ``Down with Communism!'' and ``We protected you, you've deceived us!'' a reference to the fierce battles for control of the media during the revolution. The Front ruled the country for six weeks after the uprising and now dominates the multiparty Council of National Union, which was inaugurated Friday and will rule until elections in May. Dumitru Iuga, chief of the Free Broadcasters Union, told the demonstrators that after two hours of talks he had reached an agreement with the TV authorities ``that would eradicate the last remnants of Ceausescu's tragedy and preserve what we won in December.'' He did not provide details of the agreement, which he promised would be published Tuesday in a newspaper. The protesters' primary demand was the removal of TV director-general Petre Constantin and news anchormen Gheorghe Marinescu and Petre Popescu. ``They are absolutely associated with the previous regime, therefore they are tainted and must go,'' said Valentin Balmas, a TV technician. Balmas said the demonstrators were not satisfied with the resignation Friday of broadcasting chief Aurel Dragos Munteanu, since ``censorship is not done by one man alone.'' Across town, several hundred medical students protested the refusal of the Bucharest Medical School to increase next year's class to accommodate students who have been displaced by about 400 foreign students. ``The authorities of the Bucharest Medical School, which are loyalists of the former regime, say we should admit a maximum of foreigners because we need their hard currency,'' said Gheorghe Mihai, a parent of one of the students. On Saturday, members of the 100,000-strong Romanian Drivers' Syndicate surrounded the Front's headquarters in Victory Square with several hundred trucks and buses, demanding better work conditions. About 100 army soldiers marched through Bucharest Saturday night to demand their monthly salary be increased from the current 3,000 lei, about $150, to 5,000 lei, which is about double the monthly average. They also demanded their mandatory length of service be cut in half to one year. More than 40,000 ethnic Hungarians carrying candles and books demonstrated peacefully in Tirgu Mures in central Romania on Saturday, demanding equal rights, the official Rompres news agency reported Sunday. Under Ceausescu, Romania's 2 million ethnic Hungarians frequently complained that they were subjected to forced assimilation policies, and the revolution was sparked by a protest supporting an ethnic Hungarian clergyman.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Freed After 27 Years in Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs to move up Mandela's age and SUBS 21st graf pvs to conform; pickup 22nd graf pvs, `Mandela in...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CPN5,CPN6,AB1,LaserColor CPNT,CPN8,CPN10-12
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela walked through a prison gate to freedom Sunday, setting set off joyous celebrations and violent clashes as blacks nationwide welcomed their leader back from 27 years in jail. ``Comrades and fellow South Africans, I greet you all in the name of peace, democracy and freedom for all,'' Mandela told tens of thousands of cheering supporters who thronged outside City Hall at twilight, many getting their first look at the 71-year-old African National Congress leader. But he emphatically reaffirmed his commitment to the ANC's guerrilla campaign and called for increased pressure to end white-minority domination _ the same cause that resulted in his life sentence on charges of plotting against the government. He also reiterated that talks with the government cannot begin until it lifts the state of emergency. ``I stand here before you not as a prophet, but as a humble servant of you the people,'' said the white-haired Mandela, who looked much more an elder statesman in his suit and tie than a guerrilla leader. ``Today, the majority of South Africans, black and white, recognize that apartheid has no future. It has to be ended by our decisive mass action,'' he said in a rousing half-hour speech frequently interrupted by roars of ``Viva!'' ``We have waited too long for our freedom.'' Violence broke out about the same time Mandela's motorcade arrived in Cape Town from Victor Verster prison and delayed his speech. Police said a black looter was shot to death by officers, and first aid workers said more than 100 people were injured when riot police fired shotguns after groups of black youths smashed shop windows in the city center. Some youths retaliated by hurling bottles at the officers. Hundreds of terrified people waiting to hear Mandela ran for cover as police fired blasts of shotgun pellets. Clashes between police and celebrating blacks were reported in at least two other areas, including the tribal homeland of Ciskei, where hospital officials said police shot three people to death and wounded 20. In Natal Province, where ANC supporters have been feuding with a more conservative black group, police said 12 blacks were killed in factional fighting Sunday. It was a harsh reminder of the bitter feuds involving black factions who disagree on the best way to fight for equality. Elsewhere, hundreds of thousands of blacks danced and jogged through the streets of big cities and impoverished townships, rejoicing at Mandela's freedom. ``Very good news, very good news,'' President Bush said after Mandela's release. Bush said he telephoned Mandela, told him all Americans ``were rejoicing at his release'' and invited him to the White House. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, speaking at a church service outside Cape Town shortly before Mandela was released, commended the South African government for making a ``courageous step'' but said ``the pillars of apartheid remain in place.'' A thunderous cheer went up as the man who was the world's most famous prisoner walked hand-in-hand with his wife, Winnie, through the gate of Victor Verster prison in Paarl, 35 miles from Cape Town. Under a brilliant blue sky, the Mandelas gave clenched-fist salutes to the hundreds of supporters who had waited for hours outside, many of them waving green, gold and black ANC flags and wearing T-shirts emblazoned with a youthful image of Mandela. Mandela appeared solemn and dignified as he and Winnie walked to a white BMW sedan and climbed in. He broke into a broad smile as the car set off slowly in a police-escorted motorcade. The decision to free Mandela, after a prolonged international campaign on his behalf, was announced Saturday by President F.W. de Klerk. Eight days earlier, de Klerk stunned the nation by lifting a 30-year ban on the ANC and announcing other reforms aimed at clearing the way for black-white negotiations. De Klerk, who spoke at length Saturday on Mandela's release, stayed out of the public eye Sunday. Anton Pretorius, a de Klerk spokesman, said the president planned to comment on Mandela's release later in the week. Government television, however, broadcast live Mandela's exit from prison and later showed most of the ANC leader's speech. His elderly appearance probably shocked many South Africans, the majority of whom were born after Mandela was last seen publicly in 1964. Mandela has clearly lost weight since the 1960s; both his face and his body are leaner than when he was a sturdily built boxer decades ago. His face is creased with two thick lines that frame his strong, confident smile. Mandela in his speech called de Klerk ``a man of integrity'' who had gone further than any previous National Party leader in accommodating black political aspirations. But he said further steps _ including the lifting of the state of emergency and release of all political prisoners _ must be taken before talks can begin. The ANC shares these demands. Mandela was the last well-known political prisoner in South Africa. Six of his ANC colleagues who had been imprisoned for more than 25 years, including Walter Sisulu, were released in Octobr. In the mid-1980s, Mandela rejected offers to go free in exchange for a renunciation of violence. De Klerk abandoned this condition, although he said after meeting Mandela on Friday night that he believed the black leader was ``committed to peaceful solutions.'' Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda, one of the South African government's harshest critics, urged the ANC to suspend guerrilla actions in the wake of Mandela's release. But Mandela told the Cape Town crowd the ANC resorted to violence in 1961 as a ``defensive action against the violence of apartheid,'' and added, ``The factors which necessitated the armed struggle still exist today.'' ``We have no options but to continue,'' he said. He urged whites to ``join us in the safety of a new South Africa. The freedom movement is a political home for you, too.'' Mandela, whose imprisonment included years of hard labor on windswept Robben Island in Cape Town's harbor, told his family: ``Your pain and suffering was far greater than my own.''
