DOC.HEAD: Return to Normal Winter Weather Helps Drive Gas Prices Down
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices are falling as temperatures around the nation are rising, returning the market to its normal winter patterns, industry analyst Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. Gasoline prices normally drop in the winter and rise in the summer along with national driving patterns, Lundberg said Sunday. However, they stayed higher than normal in January because unusually cold weather increased the demand for heating oil and crimped gasoline and diesel supplies at refineries, she said. When a warming trend moved across the nation in January, gas prices fell again, she said. The result was a six-tenths-of-a-cent decrease for all grades of fuel at gas pumps across the nation between Jan. 19 and Feb. 9, Lundberg said. The average price of all grades of gasoline at the nation's stations was 112.46 cents per gallon on Feb. 9, according to the national Lundberg Survey of stations across the country. Lundberg added it was too early to tell if last week's spill of an estimated 400,000 gallons of crude oil from a tanker off Huntington Beach would have any effect on future gasoline prices. ``If any suppliers or marketers or dealers have been adversely affected, we haven't heard of it,'' she said. The average prices of gasoline at self-service stations were: 100.95 cents per gallon for regular unleaded, 118.38 per gallon for premium unleaded and 99.27 for regular leaded. The prices for full-service stations were: 129.09 cents per gallon for regular unleaded, 142.51 for premium unleaded and 127.34 for regular leaded. Prices include all taxes.

DOC.HEAD: `Some Americans Abroad' by Richard Nelson Opens at Lincoln Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: The characters in Richard Nelson's ``Some Americans Abroad'' are insufferable, their actions at best trivial and at worst immoral. But Nelson is not portraying escaped convicts, white-collar criminals or even discredited politicians. The object of his satire is a group of Anglophile American academics and their students on a yearly marathon tour of British theater. It's a specialized group to skewer, and if the scope of the play, which which arrived Sunday at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center, is narrow, its aim is deadly _ and delicious. These academics from a small, unidentified American college have come to worship at the shrines of British drama _ particularly the National Theater in London and that holiest of holys _ the Royal Shakespeare Company's complex in Stratford-on-Avon. Two events turn the tour into turmoil. Both problems must be solved by the chairman of the school's English department, Joe Taylor, played with a wonderful all-enveloping smugness by Colin Stinton. Taylor is the kind of teacher who demands truth in literature if not in real life. The chairman must tell a colleague, who paid his own way over to cement his position at the school, that his contract will not be renewed. And Taylor must handle an accusation by an unstable student that she was molested by a teacher. Nelson has great fun with these people as they race from play to play to play. For them, it's quantity rather than quality that counts. These intrepid theatergoers seem more concerned with seat location, the food at intermission and how to divide the bill after dinner than with what they are watching on stage. Much of the evening's enjoyment comes from director Roger Michell's snappy production, cleverly designed by Alexandra Byrne. The furniture and props for the play's 11 scenes hang precariously above the stage. They are pulled down when needed while a jazz combo performs and then carted offstage when a scene ends. Most of the other performers are up to Stinton's high standards. Particularly effective are Bob Balaban as the nerdy assistant professor on shaky status, John Bedford Lloyd as the pompous professor accused of attacking a student and Frances Conroy as another teacher trying to conceal an affair. Nelson's best scene occurs late in the play _ at a Pizza Hut in Stratford, no less _ where the chairman and two of his professors look at and then deny the mess they have created. It's hypocrisy at its highest and wonderfully acted by Stinton, Bedford Lloyd and Conroy. Some 30 years ago, Noel Coward wrote a wicked song called ``Why Do the Wrong People Travel?'' for his musical ``Sail Away.'' In it, he poked fun at the ubiquitous American tourist who would have been better off _ and happier _ if he had stayed home. Much the same can be said for Nelson's motley collection of pretentious academics.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Japan's Northeastern Coast
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake hit the Pacific coast of northeastern Japan early Monday morning, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, police and the nation's meteorological agency said. There also were no tsunami _ huge waves that are triggered by undersea disturbances such as earthquakes or volcanic activity, the Central Meteorological Agency said. The agency said the earthquake had a preliminary reading of 5.5 on the Richter scale, a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake. Each increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of the magnitude of 5 is considered ``very strong,'' and one of 6 is capable of widespread damage if it occurs in a populated area. The temblor struck at 2:46 a.m. and was centered 24 miles under the seabed off the coast of Ibaraki prefecture, the meteorological agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Faction Calls For Voice In Coming Congress
DOC.TEXT: A group of progressive Communists on Sunday demanded a leading role in organizing this summer's party congress and threatened otherwise to hold an alternative congress. The group, calling itself the Communist Party Democratic Platform, adopted a statement that said the Communist Party Central Committee plenum last week did not go far enough in moving toward democratic reform. While the plenum agreed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal to permit multiparty elections, the group said it failed to democratize the election procedure of delegates to the party congress, set for late June or early July. ``The proposals formulated during the plenum have an inconsistent and contradictory character, which is totally inadequate to meet the demands of the existing situation,'' said the statement, obtained by The Associated Press. ``The elections (of delegates) should be direct, according to platforms, by secret ballot and with free nomination and self-nomination of candidates,'' the Democratic Platform said. The group, which includes well-known progressives such as Central Committee maverick Boris Yeltsin, economist Gavriil Popov and historian Yuri Afanasyev. Yeltsin cast the lone vote against the plenum's reform, saying it did not go far enough. The group called on Gorbachev and other members of the party's ruling Politburo to meet with the progressives to discuss their proposals for election of delegates. If their proposal is turned down or ignored by the party leadership, the Democratic Platform said it would begin planning for ``an alternative and genuinely democratic party congress.'' That would raise the possibility of the creation of an opposition faction inside the party, something the Communist leadership has implacably resisted since the days of Vladimir Lenin. Last week's plenum also condemned the vote by Lithuania's Communists to form a party independent of Moscow's control.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Opens Talks on Cambodia Peace Efforts
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the Security Council Sunday discussed ways to broaden the U.N. role in Cambodia peace efforts at a second round of talks on the issue. Representatives of the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France sat down for a working dinner to resume the talks, which began last month in Paris. A spokesman for the U.S. Mission to the United Nations said the substantive work was planned for Monday. The representatives of the countries scheduled a morning meeting with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and then planned to convene for a full day of discussions on Cambodia peace efforts. Proposals include a plan for the United Nations to administer the Southeast Asian country and supervise elections there. Diplomats familiar with the talks said the meeting is just one step in what they expect will be a lengthy process to devise an international formula aimed at bringing peace to Cambodia. The full 15-member Security Council would have to approve measures that would change the U.N.'s role. Participating in the talks are Xu Dunxin of China, Yuri Miakotnykh of the Soviet Union, David Gillmore of Britain, Claude Martin of France and Richard Soloman of the United States. After the Paris meeting, their countries issued a summary of agreed principles that said ``an effective U.N. presence'' will be required during an unspecified transition period before elections. The document said lasting peace in Cambodia can only be achieved through a political settlement that includes the verified withdrawal of foreign forces, a cease-fire and an end to outside military assistance. The Vietnamese-backed government of Cambodian Premier Hun Sen and the three guerrilla factions allied in an uneasy coalition all have given at least guarded support for a major U.N. role. The statement by the five countries in Paris made no direct mention of the Cambodian government, nor of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of a three-party guerrilla coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Teachers Plan Walkout to Protest Pay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Teachers in ...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT number of Seattle students to 43,000, sted 41,000, UPDATE with comment from Seattle school superintendent; picks up 7th graf, `The idea ...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Washington teachers plan to play hooky Tuesday and participate in marches and rallies across the state to protest a decision not to raise their salaries with a projected budget surplus. As many as 35 of the state's 296 school districts may shut down for the day because of the walkout expected by about 13,000 teachers and other education workers, affecting 200,000 students, said Washington Education Association President Carla Nuxoll. About 8,000 more members of the union also are to participate in rallies and marches over Gov. Booth Gardner's decision to ignore the organization's request for immediate 10 percent pay increases. ``We are going to the constituents and telling them that if they don't have adequately paid educational employees we aren't going to be able to deliver an educational program,'' said association spokeswoman Teresa Moore. The 49,000-member WEA represents more than 90 percent of the teaching force in the state, including 42,000 of the state's 45,000 classroom teachers and about 7,000 other staff members. Teachers in the Seattle school district _ the state's largest with about 43,000 students, 2,500 teachers and 1,500 other employees _ are among those expected to participate in the protest, said Nuxoll, and the district is scheduled to be closed. City schools Superintendent William Kendrick said in a statement that he understands the teachers' frustration and strongly supports increased funding for employee salaries. The idea for a walkout began with teachers in Everett and Edmonds after the Legislature and Gardner failed last year to make amends for salaries that slipped ever lower in the last 10 years, Moore said. When Gardner did not earmark any of a projected $611 million, 1989-91 state surplus for teacher pay raises, support for the walkout grew, Nuxoll said. The WEA wants $300 million of the surplus to pay for salary increases for teachers and other education workers. Gardner, Washington House Speaker Joe King and Senate Majority Leader Jeannette Hayner say they sympathize with teachers but the state doesn't have the money to meet their demands. The education association left it up to its chapters statewide to decide whether to participate in the protest. ``In the 1980s, Olympia always told us the money was short, but that we'd be first on the list when money was available. Now we aren't even on the list,'' said Greg Waddle, northwest regional chairman of the WEA. In some districts, school officials have expressed support for the protest. The WEA contends teacher pay in Washington state has slid from fourth in the nation a decade ago to 21st. Nuxoll said the average annual teacher salary in the state last year was $29,176 for a person with 12 years of experience, a bachelor's degree and 90 credits of postgraduate study, about $500 below the national average. Teachers received a 4 percent raise for the 1989-90 school year that was approved by the Legislature last year, and are slated to receive a 6 percent pay increase next school year. The $18,000 starting salary this year is not attracting new entrants to the profession, Nuxoll said. ``We're saying that what's at risk in this state is the ability to attract and retain the best teachers,'' she said. In Olympia, teachers plan a rally in the state Capitol Tuesday night as part of the protest. Rallies are also planned in Spokane, Yakima and Wenatchee.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters' Lawyer: Court Order Would Escalate Racial Tension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Rose Sanders ...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Roussell backing off earlier announcement that schools will reopen Monday, Mrs. Sanders' comments at rally later Sunday; picks up 10th graf, `Protesters had ...'
DOC.TEXT: Any federal court order to end sit-ins at Selma High School and City Hall would escalate racial tension stemming from the dismissal of a black school superintendent, an attorney for the protesters said Sunday. U.S. District Judge Charles Butler in Mobile scheduled a telephone conference for Monday on a request from city attorneys for a temporary restraining order halting the protests, which have kept all Selma schools closed since Wednesday. ``It probably would escalate it,'' a lawyer for the protesters, J.L. Chestnut, said of a court order. ``I don't think black people give a damn about an injunction.'' Butler said Chestnut will be included in the telephone conference. Chestnut joined about 400 other blacks outside City Hall on Sunday for a march to the high school for the second straight day. Marchers made their way through a black neighborhood chanting, ``No contract, no school,'' and ``Ain't going to let no injunction turn me around.'' The high school and City Hall were occupied for the fourth day in a row. About 20 adults and 150 students were in the high school, Mayor Joe Smitherman said. The racial turmoil began when six white members of the city school board voted Feb. 2 to dismiss Norward Roussell, the city's first black superintendent. The vote sparked protests leading to the closing of two schools Tuesday and all 11 of Selma's public schools Wednesday. Roussell was reinstated after initial protests. But students and other protesters want the school board to extend his contract, which expires June 30. Roussell said Sunday he was not sure how long schools will remain closed, backing off an announcement last week that they would reopen Monday. He said he must meet with the school board to decide the matter and has not been able to do so. Rose Sanders, a Selma attorney and one of the protesters, said she was injured as a result of police brutality during a melee at Smitherman's office Monday. A preliminary city report said allegations of police brutality at the protest were unfounded. Mrs. Sanders said at a rally at the high school later Sunday that the federal courts should not be used to undermine civil rights protesters. ``I am willing for my children to lose a year in school so their children won't have to go through this 25 years from now,'' she said. Protesters had planned both Saturday and Sunday to walk from a Selma church to the Edmund Pettus Bridge, a landmark in the civil rights movement of the 1960s, but organizers later changed the routes. Chestnut said Sunday he did not see any sign from Smitherman or other white community leaders that the protests will lead to any changes. ``I don't think you've ever had good faith on both sides of the controversy,'' Chestnut said.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Reported Agreeing To Peace Talks, Shamir's Party Torn
DOC.TEXT: The PLO secretly endorsed a U.S. plan for Israeli-Palestinian dialogue, a leading newspaper reported Sunday on the eve of a meeting that could decide Israel's next steps in the Middle East peace process. The meeting Monday of the 3,500-member Central Committee of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc is aimed at ending a power struggle in the right-wing party that has halted peace efforts by Israel's Likud-Labor coalition government. The Haaretz newspaper said the Palestine Liberation Organization agreed to proposals by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III aimed at setting up elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip of Palestinian representatives to peace talks. A text of the agreement was placed on Foreign Minister Moshe Arens' desk last week, the newspaper said. It said agreement was reached on three key points: names of Palestinian delegates to a preliminary meeting with Israelis in Cairo, Egypt, the agenda for those talks and the method for announcing the delegates' names. No further details were given. A Foreign Ministry spokesman denied knowledge of the document, saying, ``We are not aware of any such report on his (Arens') desk.'' Israel Television said two senior Baker aides are to leave for Cairo Monday to prepare a meeting of the Israeli, U.S. and Egyptian foreign ministers as the first step toward the Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. Shamir's top aide, Yossi Ben-Aharon, said he was not aware of plans for such a meeting in Cairo but confirmed Arens was due to meet with Baker in the next few days. Palestinians have been waging a 26-month-old revolt against Israeli rule of the occupied lands. In violence Sunday, Adnan Assaf, 45, died of gunshot wounds inflicted by soldiers in a clash in the West Bank town of Qabatiyah on Friday, Arab reports said. The army confirmed his death and said it was checking the circumstances. Assaf's death raised to 655 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the uprising. At least 181 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators, and 43 Israelis also have died. At Monday's Likud meeting, Shamir demands a single vote of confidence in his leadership and his peace plan for elections in the occupied territories. Hard-liners want several votes on controversial issues that threaten to split the party or even bring down the government. ``I have no compromise formula, apart from the evident one: Let the Central Committee decide what agenda it prefers,'' Shamir said Sunday. The squabble has produced two weeks of mudslinging between Shamir and Likud hawks, but some analysts said the battle could still end in a compromise, as did a Likud rift last July. Then, Shamir delivered a hard-line speech in exchange for his opponents refraining from speaking. Shamir's initiative was approved by the government last May amid American and European pressures to begin peace talks. The plan calls for negotiations with elected Palestinians on interim self-rule for the West Bank and Gaza. Later talks would decide the final status of the occupied lands. But progress toward the elections of those representatives has been slow, partly because Likud hard-liners have repeatedly tried to undercut the plan, warning it could lead to an independent Palestinian state.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Leaving Ivana Because ``It Wasn't Working Out''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with spokesman confirming split; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald Trump is ending his 12-year marriage to Ivana Trump because ``it just wasn't working out,'' a spokesman for the tycoon said Sunday. The developer told his wife last Tuesday before he left for a business trip to Tokyo that he was leaving her, said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They have a prenuptial agreement, and Mrs. Trump will receive their house in Connecticut and approximately $20 million,'' the spokesman said. ``Mr. Trump said that, while Ivana is a wonderful woman, it just wasn't working out,'' the spokesman said. Word of a split by the famous couple was first reported Sunday by Daily News columnist Liz Smith. ``While friends hope for a reconciliation, many sources tell this columnist that attorneys have already been engaged to divide the spoils,'' Smith wrote, citing unidentified sources. Forbes magazine says Trump is worth around $1.7 billion, ranking him 19th on its 1989 list of America's 400 richest people. Mrs. Trump, a socialite and former model, used to manage the Trump Castle casino and has been in charge of renovations at the Plaza Hotel in New York City. Her pay for the Plaza job, Trump said, was ``one dollar plus all the dresses she can buy.'' She refers to him as ``The Donald.'' Two months ago, Mrs. Trump said, ``I'm very happy. We have wonderful children, houses, wealth, a good marriage.'' The couple has three children. The spokesman did not know if any custody arrangements had been made regarding the children. The Trumps' holdings also include the Grand Hyatt Hotel and the flashy Trump Tower, where they have a penthouse, in New York City; the Trump Plaza and Taj Mahal in Atlantic City; the Trump Plaza in Palm Beach, Fla.; the Trump Shuttle, formerly Eastern Airlines' Northeast shuttle; a yacht, the 282-foot Trump Princess; a 45-room country home in Greenwich, Conn.; and the 150-room Mar-a-Largo mansion in Palm Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Joy, Tears Mix at As Daughter Watches Mandela's Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 6th graf, `It's just ...,' to UPDATE with more Mandela family comment; picks up 7th graf, `Mandela-Amuah plans ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AB1
DOC.TEXT: The living room of Nelson Mandela's daughter erupted in yells, tears and fists clenched in salute Sunday morning when South Africa's most famous prisoner walked free. ``When I saw him walk there, oh, I was just so excited. To see him walk out tall in a dignified way, it's just so wonderful to look at him,'' said Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah. ``It's an experience that will live for me forever. I was really elated, overjoyed, happy. I really can't express it. It was my father, seeing my father,'' she said. The 36-year-old anthropologist, a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Massachusetts, spoke in her apartment filled with television gear to catch her first glimpse of freedom for her father, imprisoned since she was 8 years old. The release of Mandela, 71, has been rumored for months, but nothing compared with actually seeing ``the father that I have never had. I see him there and I see the possibility for me to be reunited,'' she said. ``It's just so inspiring to me. I really never expected this moment, this day to come about,'' she said. Another Mandela daughter, Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, a 31-year-old student at Boston University, appeared Sunday night at a church service in Boston celebrating her father's release. ``Today is a very special day for us as members of the Mandela family. A victory has been won by our people,'' her husband, Thumbumuzi Dlamini, 39, said on behalf of the family at the service at the Cathedral of St. Paul. Dlamini urged hundreds of people gathered at the service to continue the struggle against apartheid. ``There's still much more work to be done and much more victories to be won,'' he said. Mandela-Amuah plans to return home this summer and hopes to start getting to know her father. Until then, she will stay in Amherst where she lives with her three children and her husband, Isaac, also is a doctoral student at UMass. Mandela-Amuah said she fears for her father's safety and is also concerned about the intense scrutiny he will face as he copes with the reality of being a black leader after 27 years in prison as a symbolic figure. And, she said, she hope Americans won't interpret her father's release as the end to South African blacks' struggle for equality. ``This is only the first step, a little step, and we should not forget this,'' she said. ``The battle is not over. It's only starting at a renewed, higher level.'' Mandela's other daughter in the United States, Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, 31, a student at Boston University, could not be reached by telephone Sunday at her home and did not attend a scheduled morning gathering in Cambridge. She and her husband, Thumbumuzi, and three children were scheduled to fly to South Africa early this week to be reunited with her father. ``This is what we've worked for all these years,'' she told reporters Saturday. In Boston on Sunday, Patrick Lekota, publicity secretary for the United Democratic Front and a former political prisoner who was jailed with Mandela, said Mandela's release will bring stability and strength to his cause. Lekota said the next steps for the anti-apartheid movement are to gain the release of other political prisoners and to begin negotiations to form a new constitution for the country. Mandela will meet with his comrades to map out plans for the apartheid resistance. ``Nelson is not an individualist,'' Lekota said. ``He's a team worker. He will meet with the movement to decide what the next steps are.''

DOC.HEAD: Reformers Break Away From Communist Party, Form Own Group
DOC.TEXT: A Communist Party faction impatient with the pace of reform broke away Sunday and formed its own party. The Alternative Socialist Party, in its founding declaration, called for private enterprise and limited government control of the economy. The official BTA news agency reported that as many as 600 people joined the new party. ``The Alternative Socialist Party will consider socialism not as a social system but as an inevitable trend in the development of civilization,'' said the declaration, signed by 30 intellectuals who left the Communist Party. The new party was formed from the Alternative Socialist Organization during a meeting to consider whether or not to remain in the mainstream of the ruling Communist Party. According to the declaration, read at the conference by Nikolai Vassilev, the leader of the Alternative Socialist Organization, the new party will seek allies among the ``radical and reform forces of the Bulgarian Communist Party, the Agrarian Party, the Social-Democratic Party and all democratic movements in the country,'' BTA reported. The meeting came less than two weeks after a key Communist Party Congress that chose moderate reformer Alexander Lilov as party chief and sought to present a more progressive image. The party under Lilov's predecessor Petar Mladenov, who took over from longtime hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov in November, had made some moves toward reform, including renouncing its constitutionally guaranteed leading role. During the four-day party congress, Lilov and other top officials said the party had parted with Stalinism and was embarking on a road of ``socialist democracy.'' But members of the new party said the Communist Party was not moving fast enough on reform. Speakers at Sunday's meeting criticized the party congress and the slow pace of change. Speakers who called for the formation of the Alternative Socialist Party received resounding applause from the 3,000 participants. Vassilev, a philosophy professor at Sofia University, said the party's founding congress will be held by next month.

DOC.HEAD: ``60 Minutes'' Anchorman Says Rooney Could Never Have Made Remarks on Show
DOC.TEXT: ``60 Minutes'' anchorman Mike Wallace took the opportunity during the television news magazine's broadcast Sunday to put some distance between the program and suspended humorist Andy Rooney. Rooney last week was placed on three months' suspension after racist comments were attributed to him in a gay publication. ``Even though the remarks attributed to Andy were not made on `60 Minutes' _ and indeed could never have been made on `60 Minutes' _ this is the broadcast with which he has been most closely associated,'' Wallace said. ``After his three-month suspension, which he himself has acknowledged is understandable, we, who have been his colleagues through the years, surely look forward to his return here.'' In a story published this weekend in The Advocate, a biweekly magazine based in Los Angeles, Rooney is quoted as saying blacks have watered down their genes ``because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children.'' Rooney, who won his first Emmy award in 1968 for his script for a special about blacks, flatly denied making the remarks, but said he would rather accept the suspension than end his career at CBS.

Record price increases for vegetables and fuel oil combined in January to produce the highest monthly wholesale inflation rate in 15 years, the government reported, but analysts attributed almost all of it to the holiday cold snap. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index soared a seasonally adjusted 1.8 percent last month, the sharpest rise since a 2 percent gain in November 1974, in the midst of the OPEC oil embargo. January energy prices rocketed ahead 13.6 percent for the largest monthly gain since 1974. Food costs jumped 2.1 percent, their biggest increase in six years.

Bond prices rose sharply, rallying after the successful completion of the Treasury Department's $30 billion quarterly refunding auction. The newly issued 30-year government bond surged 1 25-32 points Friday, or $17.81 for every $1,000 in face value, from its level at Thursday's auction. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, tumbled to 8.33 percent from 8.50 percent. The jump in the price of the long bond, the most widely watched of government securities, was the largest since last Oct. 13.

The deteriorating condition of the East German economy has heightened concern among officials but both German governments denied that collapse is imminent. A top official in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, speaking privately, said earlier Friday the decline, fueled by worker exodus, widespread strikes and high absenteeism at many industrial sites, has accelerated to the point that ``insolvency could be within a few days.'' Kohl will discuss the need for immediate aid in the ``billions of marks'' for East German neighbors during his weekend visit to Moscow, said the senior official.

Daniel P. Kearney, a key official in the savings and loan bureaucracy, quit after only four months on the job, dealing another blow to President Bush's dissension-plagued bailout program. Kearney is the chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, created to monitor the progress of and set the policy for government rescues of saving and loans. The job ``does not currently afford me the authority that I believe is essential to be effective in this process,'' Kearney said Friday.

Gibraltar Financial Corp. has filed for protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy law, nearly a year after regulators seized its main unit, Gibraltar Savings. Gibraltar Chairman James N. Thayer said Friday the thrift holding company was forced to make the filing Thursday to dissolve a claim against its assets by Bank of America, the trustee for the holders of $99.5 million in unsecured Gibraltar bonds. Thayer also said the move was prompted in part by the government's seizure of two of the company's savings and loan subsidiaries in March 1989.

Unsecured creditors of Allied Stores Corp. fell in line and dropped their objections to $1 billion in new financing for the retailer. Lawyers for Allied and for the creditors said Friday they agreed to a compromise similar to the one forged Thursday by Federated Department Stores and its creditors' committee. The Federated proposal is for $1.4 billion in financing. Both proposals have been submitted to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who is overseeing the Chapter 11 reorganization of the two U.S. retail divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp.

The new chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said the board's image has been ''somewhat tarnished'' and promised a non-confrontational but firm approach to public safety. James L. Kolstad, whose confirmation by the Senate late Thursday ended 17 months of uncertainty for the five-member board, said Friday he would work to improve the timeliness, quality and efficiency of efforts to ensure safety of the nation's air, land and sea transportation. The NTSB investigates all plane crashes and other major transportation accidents.

A Food and Drug Administration proposal to limit food health claims was praised as ''a major victory for consumers,'' but one industry group called portions of the plan a ``bureaucratic nightmare.'' Allen Goldberg of the Grocery Manufacturers Association on Friday praised the FDA for moving ahead on health claims, but said the plan was ``unacceptable in its current form.'' He called a requirement for FDA clearance of health claims ``a bureaucratic nightmare'' and said the need for scientific agreement on a health benefit before a claim can be made is unfair.

The stock market posted a small gain Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials edged up 3.83 points to close at 2,648.20. The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies. Bond prices rose sharply. Coffee futures prices surged to their highest levels in five months; near-month oil futures fell sharply; orange juice futures fell; precious metals slipped; grains and soybeans were higher; and livestock and meat futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Barbie Doll Cast as Ambassador of Goodwill
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On Anika Polzin's first trip outside her native East Germany in November her parents bought her a Barbie doll. Now on her second excursion to the western world the six-year-old is getting wined and dined _ make that milkshaked and hamburgered _ by Barbie's corporate parents. Mattel Inc., manufacturer of the famous fashion doll, brought Miss Polzin and her family over for a five-day holiday in New York. They will be guests at a black-tie affair Mattel is hosting tonight to mark the beginning of the annual American International Toy Fair and to announce what the company is calling the ``Barbie Summit.'' Patricia Wyatt, director of marketing for girls toys at Mattel, said the company thought it was fitting to have Miss Polzin on hand when they revealed plans for the event that is to be held each year starting with the first three-day conference in New York during the week of Nov. 19. Essay contests will be held for girls of varying ages to compete to become ``delegates.'' ``Through Barbie we want to bring children from around the world together,'' Ms. Wyatt said, speaking in the almost reverential tones Mattel people use in referring to a toy that has been a must-have for many little girls since being introduced 31 years ago. Mattel reckons that enough Barbies have been sold in the doll's lifetime that if placed head to toe they would circle the earth 3{ times. Sales of the dolls plus her entourage and their accouterments exceeded $450 million in 1988 and accounted for 40 percent of Hawthorne, Calif.-based Mattel's total revenue. The summit will ``give children a forum to express their viewpoints'' ... and ``help them share their different cultures with one another,'' Ms. Wyatt said in an interview. A new Barbie Summit doll _ appropriately available in four ethnic distinctions _ outfitted in a shimmering white ensemble will debut at Toy Fair, an annual trade show. Proceeds from sales of the doll will be placed in a Barbie Fund, which Mattel will donate to children's charities. The towheaded Miss Polzin was tuckered out Friday afternoon from a busy day of sightseeing, shopping and a visit to Rumpelmayer's Restaurant, a favorite Manhattan watering hole with the young, ice-cream eating set. But she handled an interview at her Waldorf Astoria suite with admirable aplomb and smiled sweetly for photographs. It was a picture of a beaming Anika clutching a new Barbie that first attracted Mattel's attention. ``We were very moved by the photo,'' Ms. Wyatt said. ``It was nice to know that Barbie transcended cultures.'' The caption on the photo, which appeared in newspapers around the world, gave her name and hometown, Schwanefeld, East Germany. It said she was photographed after a day of western-style shopping in Helmstedt, West Germany. Mattel's German affiliates easily tracked down Miss Polzin. Only a few inquiries were needed to trace her in Schwanefeld, a tiny village, population 270, a few miles from the border with West Germany. Miss Polzin, wearing a new dress and complementing hot-pink tights, said through an interpreter that she was enjoying her trip to the United States. But signs of jet lag were still evident as she sat on a sofa beside Minnie Mouse. She and her 10-year-old brother, Maik, and parents, Eva and Inglof, who works for the East German railroad, arrived late Thursday night from Frankfurt on a flight courtesy of Lufthansa airlines. They already had been to the Statue of Liberty, and outings to the Empire State Building, museums and, of course, FAO Schwarz were planned.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Protection Should Not Hamper Free Trade, Experts Say
Eds.: InterAction in 3rd graf is CQ.
DOC.TEXT: Measures to protect the environment should not jeopardize worldwide economic growth, a high-level panel of experts said here Sunday. ``There is no doubt that it is totally irresponsible to further postpone forceful measures'' to contain further damage to the earth's environment, said Emile van Lennep, a former Secretary-General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). ``But such measures should not lead to any unfair competition on the world's markets,'' said Van Lennep, a member of a group of experts that met here to draw up a report for the InterAction Council. The Council, founded seven years ago and chaired by former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, is a loosely-knit association of 30 former heads of government who meet annually to discuss environmental issues such as population growth, deforestation, and energy supplies. Among the participants at the weekend meeting, which was in preparation of next May's annual meeting in Seoul, South Korea, were former British Prime Minister Lord Callaghan and Miguel de la Madrid, the former Mexican president. ``An important task for governments in the coming decade will be to take care of environmental conservation and at the same time see to it such conservatory measures will not be detrimental to economic growth,'' Van Lennep said. And he said that the group of experts here ``emphasized that the pricing instrument should be used as much as possible ... so that the environmental cost of a given product is reflected in its price.'' Van Lennep said the experts voiced ``grave reservations'' against government subsidies to their local industries to cushion the effect of environmental costs on their products' pricing. The former OECD chief said the experts also would recommend a huge transfer of funds to Third World and Eastern European nations to gear their industries to environmental needs.

DOC.HEAD: Growth Rate Fell to 1.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's annual economic growth rate slowed to 1.7 percent last year while some six percent of the country`s citizens live close to the poverty line, a newspaper said. ``The annual growth dynamics of the GNP slowed to 1.7 percent, down from 2.8 percent, according to preliminary estimates,'' Mlada Fronta quoted the official federal statistics report as saying. The newspaper on Saturday said the average growth rate in industrialized countries is estimated at 3.6 percent. Czechoslovakia's national income _ the rough equivalent of GNP _ is 58O billion crowns, or some $34 billion, the report said. The crown cannot be converted freely into dollars or other Western currencies. The report said high energy consumption in Czechoslovakia's inefficient economy as well as the sharply reduced output of the country's military industry contributed to the growth slowdown. Vast amounts of idle stock, roughly equivalent to one year's GNP, also have slowed the economy, Mlada Fronta said. ``In 1988, there were ... almost 900,000 people whose average per capita income was lower than 1,000 Czechoslovak crowns ($59) _ that's on the verge of the poverty line, '' the newspaper said. The average monthy income for Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million population is 3,200 crowns ($188), up by 2.4 percent in 1989 from the previous year, the report said. Czechoslovakia's centrally planned economy, which has timidly introduced some elements of market mechanism in recent years, so far failed to produce notable results.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Offshore Bank To Channel Profits to Loan Loss Fund
DOC.TEXT: Arab Banking Corp., Bahrain's largest offshore bank, said it was setting aside its entire 1989 profit of $132 million to cover potential loan losses. ABC, which is owned by the governments of Kuwait, Libya and Abu Dhabi, said Sunday the addition to its loan-loss reserve was needed to reassure investors because the bank is planning a $250-million share offering to boost its capital by 25 percent. Troubles with the bank's Latin American loan portfolio helped cause interest income to fall 14 percent to $327 million in 1989 from $380 million in 1988. The drop largely reflected non-payment of interest by Brazil and Argentina, said Abdullah Saudi, the bank's president and chief executive. The drop in interest income was offset in part by an increase in fees and commissions, which rose 30 percent to $179 million last year from $138 million in 1988. Operating profit before taxes, minority items and loan loss provisions fell to $184 million in 1989 from $239 million. Saudi said the addition to reserves would boost the bank's provisions for doubtful loans to about 40 percent of its loan portfolio. Saudi said the $250-million share issue planned for the first half of this year will be listed in the Bahrain, Kuwait and Luxembourg stock exchanges. Funds raised through the share issue will go in part toward the setting up of a new ABC European subsidiary, Saudi said. The new company, provisionally named ABC Europe, will take care of ABC branches in Paris, Milan and London. It is likely to be based in London. Saudi said he hoped the bank also would expand in the Arab world.

DOC.HEAD: AP Business News
Fast Food, Soft Drink Industries Register Support for Recycling Tax
DOC.TEXT: Fast-food and soft drink giants, expecting to be called on to help solve the nation's solid waste problem, are taking the unusual stance of supporting taxes on themselves in that endeavor. Companies such as Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers Inc., McDonald's Corp., PepsiCo Inc. and Coca-Cola Co. are the leading users of polystyrene food containers, aluminum cans and plastic and glass bottles. And they have been feeling enough heat from consumers concerned about the garbage choking the nation's landfills to suggest a tax on themselves by a government they believe will eventually tax them anyway. In the last few months, representatives of the companies have been working to draft proposals for legislation that would place a levy on their own use of unrecycled materials. ``We're trying to find a way to encourage recycling on a national level,'' said Malcolm Chester, vice president of public affairs for Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers, a subsidiary of Chicago-based Whitman Corp. and the country's largest independent soft drink bottler. But Paul Risley, an aide to Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., head of the subcommittee planning hearings on the 1990 Clean Air Act, said the companies are drawing up their own proposals because they're ``afraid of'' what might be included in a renewal of the Recycling Conservation and Recovery Act of 1980. The Bush administration had been expected to put specific recycling provisions in its budget proposal _ possibly a ``user fee'' or tax on virgin materials produced by paper mills, plastic plants, steel mills and glass manufacturers. But Senate sources said the administration would concentrate first on getting the Clean Air Act passed by early summer. ``If the federal government doesn't come with something this year, it may be too late,'' said Sal Porazzo, director of environmental affairs at Pepsi-Cola Co., whose parent company also owns the Kentucky Fried Chicken, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut chains. ``It's already happening at the state level,'' Porazzo said. About 10 percent of all beer and soft drink containers are being recycled, but ``the number is moving up rapidly,'' said Chester, of Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers. About 64 percent of the country's growing mountain of solid waste is paper and paperboard, metals, glass and plastics, according to Pepsi-Cola. Although Pepsi-Cola claims that soft drink and fast-food containers account for only 2.25 percent of that sold waste after recycling, the public still sees them as the biggest solid waste problem. Coca-Cola is talking with the retail grocery trade and congressional staff members about ``several proposals, including fess for the use of virgin material,'' said spokesman Randy Donaldson. ``We're laying out alternatives and getting feedback.'' Oak Brook-based McDonald's, the largest fast-food chain, is talking to its suppliers about user fees for unrecycled materials as well, said spokesman Armando Ojeda. Ojeda said the chain, which recently announced plans to recycle waste from 450 restaurants in five New England states, would like to see action on the user fees at a national level.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers' Profits Increase Eightfold but Company to Restructure
DOC.TEXT: Travelers Corp. recorded an eightfold increase in profits for 1989 despite a 40 percent decline in the fourth quarter, the company said. Higher earnings for the year resulted partly from improved results in employee benefits and asset management and pension services. But personal property-casualty insurance, which includes auto and homeowners' lines, lost $12.7 million last year, the company reported Friday. Facing mounting losses in personal insurance, the company said it would restructure the operations and become choosier about where it sells coverage. Net income for 1989 rose to $455 million, or $4.37 a share, from $55 million, or 44 cents a share, for 1988. Fourth quarter net income dropped to $149 million, or $1.42 a share, from $250 million, or $2.47 a share, in 1988. Catastrophe losses from Hurricane Hugo, the San Francisco earthquake and other disasters totaled $86 million in 1989, compared with $21 million from similar disasters in 1988. Fourth-quarter earnings in 1989 include gains of $56 million from the sale of Keystone Group Inc. and $20 million of losses from catastrophes. In the 1988 final quarter, profits included $107 million of gains from the sale of several businesses and investment properties and $7 million of catastrophe losses. Revenues for 1989 totaled $12.5 billion, up from $12.3 billion a year ago. Premiums were $7.8 billion, the same as in 1988. Fourth quarter revenues totaled $3.2 billion, compared with $3 billion in the 1988 quarter. Premiums rose to $1.9 billion from $1.6 billion. Travelers said the net loss of nearly $13 million in 1989 in personal property-casualty lines compared with $29 million of net income in 1988. Catastrophe claims and regulators' restrictions on price increases contributed to the 1989 loss, said Edward H. Budd, chairman and chief executive officer. Under the restructuring announced Friday, some jobs will be cut, field offices will be consolidated and the number of independent agents selling Travelers' consumer insurance lines will be reduced.

DOC.HEAD: Loral To Eliminate 100 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Loral Defense Systems in Akron says it will eliminate 100 jobs and discontinue its electronics assembly operation on April 13. The company informed union officials of the job cuts Friday. Loral Defense Systems, the Akron area's eighth-largest employer, is a unit of Loral Corp. of New York, the nation's 35th-largest defense contractor. Loral last month threatened to move the electronics assembly workers' jobs to an area with cheaper labor costs if the union did not agree to contract concessions. The company said it needed to improve its ability to compete. Loral employs about 320 hourly and 1,600 salaried workers in Akron. UAW Local 856 President Tom Seese said the union refused Loral's demands that workers take a 50 percent reduction in their pay and benefits package. They are making about $24 an hour in combined wages and fringe benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Planning More Salaried Work Force Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Sunday it will cut deeper into its salaried work force as it continues with an accelerated cost-cutting program. The nation's No. 3 automaker in October announced a program designed to carve $1 billion in costs from its $26 billion budget by the end of 1990. At that time, Chrysler said 2,300 salaried employees, or 8 percent of its 31,000-member white-collar work force, would be removed from its payroll. Chrysler spokesman Steve Harris said Sunday that more white-collar workers would be cut through attrition. He said he couldn't say how many positions the company planned to eliminate, and he knew of no plans for further layoffs. Automotive News, a weekly industry journal, quoted unidentified sources in its Monday's editions as saying the new round of cuts would remove 5 percent to 10 percent of the company's salaried work force, in addition to those announced in October. ``White-collar reductions are becoming a way of life at Chrysler,'' Harris said. ``A certain part will come through attrition.'' General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. have said they, like Chrysler, constantly are reviewing their employment levels. In 1987, GM began its ``Action Plan,'' to cut costs. Since then, its original target has been raised to $13 billion by 1991. Ford has no formal cost-cutting plan similar to GM's or Chrysler's. The automakers will give better pictures of changes in their employment levels later this week when they report 1989 earnings. The latest salaried work-force reduction at Chrysler is likely to be met favorably on Wall Street, said auto analyst Thomas O'Grady, president of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc. of Wayne, Pa. ``What I would be concerned about is what they are doing with the savings,'' he said Sunday. ``If it is just to have a better bottom line, that's not so good.'' He suggested that the company funnel the money into product development. There was no indication from Harris about where the savings would be sent, but if the job cuts were part of the overall cost-reduction program, it would be unlikely that product development would get much. Auto analyst Steve Girsky of PaineWebber Inc. in New York City said the newest cuts should be well received. ``I think this company is serious about slimming down,'' he said.
